title: Class Day 2021 Speaker: Senator Elizabeth Warren
desc: Elizabeth Warren, U.S. senator from Massachusetts and the Leo Gottlieb Professor of Law, Emerita at Harvard Law School, spoke at the Harvard Law School Class Day ceremony on May, 26, 2021.         In her remarks, Warren outlined what she views as the greatest challenges in the United States today â€“ economic inequality, a shrinking middle class, racial injustice, climate change, and threats to democracy itself â€“ and encouraged students to use their education and influence to find new ways to address these issues in the future.        Read the story here: https://today.law.harvard.edu/have-courage-elizabeth-warren-urges-harvard-law-schools-class-of-2021/

00:02:15.500 --> 00:02:20.150    Our community of collaboration converted to    one of crippling comparisons.        45    00:02:20.150 --> 00:02:24.290    Suddenly our aspirations to pursue progress,        46    00:02:24.290 --> 00:02:29.070    were limited by our desperation to preserve status.        47    00:02:29.070 --> 00:02:33.140    We began believing that our purpose lay in    our importance,        48    00:02:33.140 --> 00:02:35.190    but we forfeited our power.        49    00:02:35.190 --> 00:02:39.540    We saw our galaxy of greatness stripped of    the light of possibility,        50    00:02:39.540 --> 00:02:42.410    subdued by the darkness of self-doubt.        51    00:02:42.410 --> 00:02:43.640    At that confusing junction,        52    00:02:43.640 --> 00:02:44.820    many were asking themselves,        53    00:02:44.820 --> 00:02:49.530    "Is this all I really came to Harvard to become?"        54    00:02:49.530 --> 00:02:53.810    But what if we open the door to a different reality?        55    00:02:53.810 --> 00:02:58.090    What if we already have the keys?        56    00:02:58.090 --> 00:03:02.070    The first key from my mom said "Believe."        57    00:03:02.070 --> 00:03:03.900    Could she have been asking us to believe        58    00:03:03.900 --> 00:03:08.090    that we never really came to Harvard to acquire accolades,        59    00:03:08.090 --> 00:03:13.810    but that success is second rate to soul saved    and lives made better.        60    00:03:13.810 --> 00:03:16.130    The second key said "Fearless."        61    00:03:16.130 --> 00:03:20.350    Did she know that the path to purpose might    be unpopular,        62    00:03:20.350 --> 00:03:22.020    but if we clung to that fear of rejection,        63    00:03:22.020 --> 00:03:25.290    we might fail to offer the world what was    ours to give?        64    00:03:25.290 --> 00:03:27.850    The last key said "Inspire."        65    00:03:27.850 --> 00:03:31.570    Might she have understood that if we did not    become leaders of sacrifice,        66    00:03:31.570 --> 00:03:36.590    we would become leaders of selfishness but    we would be leaders either way.        67    00:03:36.590 --> 00:03:39.430    When my dad said Harvard is your canvas,        68    00:03:39.430 --> 00:03:42.480    was he not giving us the confidence to emerge    from the college,        69    00:03:42.480 --> 00:03:43.650    and the Kennedy School,        70    00:03:43.650 --> 00:03:45.690    and the business school,     and the divinity school,        71    00:03:45.690 --> 00:03:46.690    and the design school,        72    00:03:46.690 --> 00:03:48.480    and the law school, the medical school,        73    00:03:48.480 --> 00:03:51.870    the education school, the extension school,    the dental school,        74    00:03:51.870 --> 00:03:54.450    and every other school at Harvard,        75    00:03:54.450 --> 00:03:57.870    painting portraits with our presence as a    community of artists        76    00:03:57.870 --> 00:04:02.860    and not imitators of key makers and not gatekeepers.        77    00:04:02.860 --> 00:04:04.560    As I stand here today,        78    00:04:04.560 --> 00:04:09.170    my answer to all of these questions is a resounding Yes.        79    00:04:09.170 --> 00:04:11.150    And if yours is too,        80    00:04:11.150 --> 00:04:14.610    then we can leave our galaxy of greatness    and land back on Earth        81    00:04:14.610 --> 00:04:18.519    with such an unyielding collision that the    paradigms of broken systems and        82    00:04:18.519 --> 00:04:21.769    mediocre standards might splatter like gas    and dust in a        83    00:04:21.769 --> 00:04:25.620    supernova.        84    00:04:25.620 --> 00:04:30.560    In the midst of this historic global    pandemic.        85    00:04:30.560 --> 00:04:35.169    This message carries more weight than it ever    has before.        86    00:04:35.169 --> 00:04:39.219    Use our powers for good.        87    00:04:39.219 --> 00:04:40.930    That by those deeds we might demonstrate that        88    00:04:40.930 --> 00:04:44.479    our gifts are not a solemn path to importance,        89    00:04:44.479 --> 00:04:48.990    but a promise for another person.        90    00:04:48.990 --> 00:04:52.280    Harvard will change you,        91    00:04:52.280 --> 00:04:55.370    but let it continue to change you.        92    00:04:55.370 --> 00:04:59.110    Let it make you keenly sensitive to injustice.        93    00:04:59.110 --> 00:05:02.879    Let it make you more empathetic to struggle.        94    00:05:02.879 --> 00:05:06.620    Let it embolden you to make change.        95    00:05:06.620 --> 00:05:09.009    Let it make you all of these things because    to become anything        96    00:05:09.009 --> 00:05:16.580    else would be to forfeit any meaning in being    a Harvard graduate.        97    00:05:16.580 --> 00:05:18.639    We were fortunate to fly high enough that    we might        98    00:05:18.639 --> 00:05:24.770    grab the moral arc of the universe itself.        99    00:05:24.770 --> 00:05:29.099    May we bend it in the right direction.

title: Graduate English Address by Sana Raoof | Honoring the Harvard Class of 2020
desc: Graduate English speaker Sana Raoof A.B. â€™12, Ph.D. â€™18, M.D. â€™20 addresses fellow students in the Class of 2020 virtual celebration ceremony on May 28, 2020.
speech_raw: 1    00:00:00.849 --> 00:00:05.440    SANA RAOOF >> When beloved Harvard Professor E. O. Wilson was seven,        2    00:00:05.440 --> 00:00:08.440    he got a fish bone stuck in his eyeball.        3    00:00:08.440 --> 00:00:11.530    After that, he couldn't see things far away,        4    00:00:11.530 --> 00:00:15.820    so he decided to look at small things closely.        5    00:00:15.820 --> 00:00:17.850    Gazing into a microscope,        6    00:00:17.850 --> 00:00:20.610    Ed fell in love with ants.        7    00:00:20.610 --> 00:00:22.840    After decades studying them,        8    00:00:22.840 --> 00:00:25.190    he explained that every species,        9    00:00:25.190 --> 00:00:31.770    even an ant, represents an evolutionary journey    of 3.9 billion years.        10    00:00:31.770 --> 00:00:36.899    That fish bone forced Ed to see the world    from a new perspective.        11    00:00:36.899 --> 00:00:42.870    Professor Wilson's story mirrors the phenomenon    he spent his life studying, evolution.        12    00:00:42.870 --> 00:00:47.649    I studied evolution in lab during my PhD.        13    00:00:47.649 --> 00:00:52.010    Evolution is driven by challenges causing    adaptations.        14    00:00:52.010 --> 00:00:53.479    Challenged with tall trees,        15    00:00:53.479 --> 00:00:56.420    giraffes evolved long necks.        16    00:00:56.420 --> 00:00:57.769    Challenged with hard seeds,        17    00:00:57.769 --> 00:00:59.589    birds evolved tough peaks.        18    00:00:59.589 --> 00:01:03.160    Through a series of environmental challenges,        19    00:01:03.160 --> 00:01:11.340    evolution transformed life from a wriggling    RNA molecule to a diverse human society.        20    00:01:11.340 --> 00:01:14.260    Outside my lab, I saw that challenges are        21    00:01:14.270 --> 00:01:17.940    the building blocks of not only biological    adaptations,        22    00:01:17.940 --> 00:01:20.450    but also personal evolution.        23    00:01:20.450 --> 00:01:24.800    I learned this from my grandfather, Dr. Abdul Raoof.        24    00:01:24.800 --> 00:01:30.109    His story began as an orphan in India, struggling    for food and shelter.        25    00:01:30.109 --> 00:01:32.280    In hopes of a scholarship,        26    00:01:32.280 --> 00:01:36.039    he studied under streetlights swarming with bugs.        27    00:01:36.039 --> 00:01:41.799    He finally won a scholarship to Columbia University    where he earned a PhD.        28    00:01:41.799 --> 00:01:43.880    He became a teacher of children,        29    00:01:43.880 --> 00:01:47.619    then a principal, then a teacher of teachers.        30    00:01:47.619 --> 00:01:51.579    My grandfather's mission evolved from early    challenges.        31    00:01:51.579 --> 00:01:53.179    Education gave him freedom,        32    00:01:53.179 --> 00:01:55.270    so he became an educator.        33    00:01:55.270 --> 00:01:59.590    Hungry in childhood, he provided food for    his students.        34    00:01:59.590 --> 00:02:01.049    Homeless in his village,        35    00:02:01.049 --> 00:02:05.360    he housed people under his own roof and dependent    on scholarships,        36    00:02:05.360 --> 00:02:09.100    he funded scholarships for students in need.        37    00:02:09.100 --> 00:02:12.330    In these ways, from so simple a beginning,        38    00:02:12.330 --> 00:02:15.360    my grandfather's life evolved a mission.        39    00:02:15.360 --> 00:02:18.510    Over 40 years, he built schools,        40    00:02:18.510 --> 00:02:22.040    developed curricula and trained teachers in    Bhutan,        41    00:02:22.040 --> 00:02:25.190    Afghanistan, Kenya ,and India.        42    00:02:25.190 --> 00:02:30.680    He retired as a director of UNESCO, having    educated thousands.        43    00:02:30.680 --> 00:02:35.920    He dedicated the last chapter of his life    to educating just two,        44    00:02:35.920 --> 00:02:38.600    my brother and me.        45    00:02:38.600 --> 00:02:40.790    It was not his Ivy League degree,        46    00:02:40.790 --> 00:02:45.580    but his experience at the bottom of society    that propelled him.        47    00:02:45.580 --> 00:02:48.790    My grandfather and Professor Wilson,        48    00:02:48.790 --> 00:02:52.440    teach us that our challenges help us develop    our strengths.        49    00:02:52.440 --> 00:02:57.330    What Professor Wilson lost in sight, he gained    in vision.        50    00:02:57.330 --> 00:02:59.890    My grandfather, powerless in youth,        51    00:02:59.890 --> 00:03:04.800    spent his life empowering others.        52    00:03:04.800 --> 00:03:10.720    Fellow graduates, 2020 has gotten off to a    very rough start.        53    00:03:10.720 --> 00:03:16.260    Illness, isolation, and insecurities weigh    on all of us.        54    00:03:16.260 --> 00:03:21.230    Coronavirus has also unmasked deep troubles    in our societies.        55    00:03:21.230 --> 00:03:23.770    Facing patients who couldn't breathe,        56    00:03:23.770 --> 00:03:29.280    we medical students had to share ventilators    and ration oxygen among them.        57    00:03:29.280 --> 00:03:31.160    Public health students witnessed the difficulty of        58    00:03:31.160 --> 00:03:34.790    mobilizing medical resources due to politics,        59    00:03:34.790 --> 00:03:38.980    inadequate planning, and inconsistent public education.        60    00:03:38.980 --> 00:03:43.370    Business students saw how brittle our economy    is when confronting crisis,        61    00:03:43.370 --> 00:03:46.300    especially for the most vulnerable among us;        62    00:03:46.300 --> 00:03:50.390    the hourly workers, the homeless, the forgotten.        63    00:03:50.390 --> 00:03:52.270    In times like these,        64    00:03:52.270 --> 00:03:55.030    we can remember that the greater the adversity,        65    00:03:55.030 --> 00:03:58.250    the greater the need for evolution on all    scales,        66    00:03:58.250 --> 00:04:05.740    from the individual to the nation and historic    times have inspired historic innovations.        67    00:04:05.740 --> 00:04:07.590    During the Great Plague,        68    00:04:07.590 --> 00:04:12.220    isolated in quarantine, Isaac Newton discovered    gravity,        69    00:04:12.220 --> 00:04:14.740    optical physics, and calculus.        70    00:04:14.740 --> 00:04:16.840    After World War II,        71    00:04:16.840 --> 00:04:18.900    in a Harvard commencement speech,        72    00:04:18.900 --> 00:04:21.370    George Marshall announced the Marshall Plan,        73    00:04:21.370 --> 00:04:24.870    lifting millions out of poverty.        74    00:04:24.870 --> 00:04:28.790    We are, once again, at a challenging moment.        75    00:04:28.790 --> 00:04:32.760    But let us remember that challenges inspire    evolution,        76    00:04:32.760 --> 00:04:36.910    and evolution that Harvard graduates can direct.        77    00:04:36.910 --> 00:04:38.370    We study the law,        78    00:04:38.370 --> 00:04:41.500    engineering, history, medicine, divinity.        79    00:04:41.500 --> 00:04:44.870    This pandemic has uncovered the world's needs.        80    00:04:44.870 --> 00:04:49.490    How can we adapt to serve our communities    or future generations?        81    00:04:49.490 --> 00:04:53.490    This is our opportunity to evolve ourselves    from        82    00:04:53.490 --> 00:05:00.130    students of arts and sciences to drivers of    social progress and innovation.        83    00:05:00.130 --> 00:05:01.510    My grandfather told me,        84    00:05:01.510 --> 00:05:07.190    "Make a plan to change the world and do not    rest until you achieve it."        85    00:05:07.190 --> 00:05:10.710    It's now, when we're at our lowest points,        86    00:05:10.710 --> 00:05:12.850    that we look internally,        87    00:05:12.850 --> 00:05:15.090    develop our strengths, and gain the vision        88    00:05:15.090 --> 00:05:18.900    that may lead us to our highest points in    the future.        89    00:05:18.900 --> 00:05:22.630    So graduates, let us turn this disruption    into        90    00:05:22.630 --> 00:05:27.490    our vision and this challenge into our evolution.

title: Washington Post Executive Editor Marty Baron Delivers Address | Honoring the Harvard Class of 2020
desc: Washington Post Executive Editor Marty Baron delivers a special address honoring the Harvard Class of 2020 on May 28, 2020.
speech_raw: 1    00:00:00.570 --> 00:00:03.489    Good morning from my home.        2    00:00:03.489 --> 00:00:07.850    Like you, I wish we were together on campus.        3    00:00:07.850 --> 00:00:11.879    There's so much now we can no longer take    for granted.        4    00:00:11.879 --> 00:00:15.619    The air we breathe is first among them.        5    00:00:15.619 --> 00:00:20.970    So those of us who are healthy have ample    reason to be grateful.        6    00:00:20.970 --> 00:00:26.070    I'm also grateful to Harvard and to President    Bacow for inviting me to be with you.        7    00:00:26.070 --> 00:00:30.140    To the Harvard Class of 2020, congratulations,        8    00:00:30.140 --> 00:00:32.590    and congratulations to the parents, professors,        9    00:00:32.590 --> 00:00:36.750    mentors, and friends who helped you along    the way.        10    00:00:36.750 --> 00:00:40.050    Joining you for graduation is a high honor.        11    00:00:40.050 --> 00:00:43.559    For me this is an opportunity,        12    00:00:43.559 --> 00:00:49.170    an opportunity to speak about subjects that    I believe are of real urgency,        13    00:00:49.170 --> 00:00:54.550    especially now during a worldwide health emergency.        14    00:00:54.550 --> 00:01:00.699    I would like to discuss with you the need    for a commitment to facts and the truth.        15    00:01:00.699 --> 00:01:01.699    Only a few months ago,        16    00:01:01.699 --> 00:01:07.000    I would have settled for emphasizing that    our democracy depends on facts and truth,        17    00:01:07.000 --> 00:01:08.979    and it truly does.        18    00:01:08.979 --> 00:01:11.450    But now as we can plainly see,        19    00:01:11.450 --> 00:01:14.750    it is more elemental than that.        20    00:01:14.750 --> 00:01:18.570    Facts and truth are matters of life and death.        21    00:01:18.570 --> 00:01:25.930    Misinformation, disinformation, delusions,    and deceit can kill.        22    00:01:25.930 --> 00:01:29.890    Here is what can move us forward: science    and medicine,        23    00:01:29.890 --> 00:01:33.720    study and knowledge, expertise, and reason.        24    00:01:33.720 --> 00:01:39.040    In other words, fact and truth.        25    00:01:39.040 --> 00:01:43.790    I want to tell you why free expression by    all of us and an independent press,        26    00:01:43.790 --> 00:01:45.600    imperfect though we may be,        27    00:01:45.600 --> 00:01:48.380    is essential to getting at the truth,        28    00:01:48.380 --> 00:01:51.409    and why we must hold the government to account,        29    00:01:51.409 --> 00:01:54.729    and hold other powerful interests to account    as well.        30    00:01:54.729 --> 00:01:57.790    When I began thinking about these remarks,        31    00:01:57.790 --> 00:01:59.200    I expected, of course,        32    00:01:59.200 --> 00:02:01.430    to be on Harvard's campus,        33    00:02:01.430 --> 00:02:05.560    and I thought not a bad place to talk about    a free press,        34    00:02:05.560 --> 00:02:10.410    not a bad place to talk about our often testy    relationship with official power.        35    00:02:10.410 --> 00:02:13.380    It was in Boston after all where        36    00:02:13.380 --> 00:02:17.120    the first newspaper of the American colonies    was founded.        37    00:02:17.120 --> 00:02:22.150    Its first edition was published September    25th, 1690.        38    00:02:22.150 --> 00:02:27.270    The very next day, the Governor and Council    of Massachusetts shut it down.        39    00:02:27.270 --> 00:02:29.970    So the press of this country has long known    what it        40    00:02:29.970 --> 00:02:34.170    means to face a government that aims to silence    it.        41    00:02:34.170 --> 00:02:37.890    Fortunately, there has been progress.        42    00:02:37.890 --> 00:02:38.890    With the First Amendment,        43    00:02:38.890 --> 00:02:45.100    James Madison championed the right of "freely    examining public characters and measures".        44    00:02:45.100 --> 00:02:47.670    But it took a very long time before we as    a nation        45    00:02:47.670 --> 00:02:51.840    fully absorbed what Madison was talking about.        46    00:02:51.840 --> 00:02:54.530    We took many ominous turns.        47    00:02:54.530 --> 00:02:58.420    We had the Alien and Sedition Acts under John    Adams,        48    00:02:58.420 --> 00:03:04.290    the Sedition and Espionage Acts under Woodrow    Wilson, the McCarthy era.        49    00:03:04.290 --> 00:03:09.110    It was not always clear where we, as a nation,    would end up.        50    00:03:09.110 --> 00:03:14.390    Finally, witnessing the authoritarianism of    Nazi Germany and Imperial Japan,        51    00:03:14.390 --> 00:03:18.190    we began to secure a free press in this country.        52    00:03:18.190 --> 00:03:20.270    The Supreme Court would forcefully emphasize        53    00:03:20.270 --> 00:03:25.140    the press's role in guaranteeing a democracy.        54    00:03:25.140 --> 00:03:27.870    Justice Hugo Black said it well decades later,        55    00:03:27.870 --> 00:03:30.700    ''The press was protected so that it could    bare        56    00:03:30.700 --> 00:03:33.750    the secrets of government and inform the people.''        57    00:03:33.750 --> 00:03:39.120    Not only the secrets of government, I would    add,        58    00:03:39.120 --> 00:03:42.950    our duty to inform the public does not stop    there,        59    00:03:42.950 --> 00:03:45.830    not by a long shot.        60    00:03:45.830 --> 00:03:49.750    That was evident during my years as a journalist    in Boston.        61    00:03:49.750 --> 00:03:55.870    Amid today's crisis, it seems like another    era, and I guess it is.        62    00:03:55.870 --> 00:03:58.370    But I want to tell you about it because I    think it remains        63    00:03:58.370 --> 00:04:03.230    instructive about what a strong independent    press must do.        64    00:04:03.230 --> 00:04:08.700    I started as editor of The Boston Globe in    the summer of 2001.        65    00:04:08.700 --> 00:04:10.500    One day, prior to my start date,        66    00:04:10.500 --> 00:04:13.200    a Globe columnist wrote about a shocking case.        67    00:04:13.200 --> 00:04:17.850    A priest had been accused of abusing as many    as 80 kids.        68    00:04:17.850 --> 00:04:24.370    A lawsuit alleged that the cardinal in Boston    at the time knew about the serial abuse,        69    00:04:24.370 --> 00:04:26.090    didn't do anything about it,        70    00:04:26.090 --> 00:04:33.740    and repeatedly reassign this priest from parish    to parish warning no one over decades.        71    00:04:33.740 --> 00:04:37.850    The archdiocese called the accusations baseless    and reckless.        72    00:04:37.850 --> 00:04:41.600    The Globe columnist wrote that the truth might    never be known.        73    00:04:41.600 --> 00:04:46.840    Internal documents that might reveal it had    been sealed by a judge.        74    00:04:46.840 --> 00:04:47.840    On my first day of work,        75    00:04:47.840 --> 00:04:49.250    we asked the question,        76    00:04:49.250 --> 00:04:55.870    ''How do we get at the truth because the public    deserve to know?"        77    00:04:55.870 --> 00:04:59.470    That question led us to challenge the judge's    secrecy order,        78    00:04:59.470 --> 00:05:03.980    and our journalists launched an investigation    of their own.        79    00:05:03.980 --> 00:05:08.420    In early 2002, we published what we had learned    through        80    00:05:08.420 --> 00:05:13.460    reporting and by prevailing in court. We published    the truth.        81    00:05:13.460 --> 00:05:16.620    The cardinal did know about the abuse by this    priest,        82    00:05:16.620 --> 00:05:19.760    yet he kept him in ministry,        83    00:05:19.760 --> 00:05:22.960    thus enabling further abuse.        84    00:05:22.960 --> 00:05:27.150    Dozens of clergy in the diocese had committed    similar offenses.        85    00:05:27.150 --> 00:05:32.670    The cardinal had covered it all up and a bigger    truth would emerge.        86    00:05:32.670 --> 00:05:38.160    Covering up such abuse had been practiced    in policy in the church for decades.        87    00:05:38.160 --> 00:05:42.820    Only now the powerful were being held to account.        88    00:05:42.820 --> 00:05:46.710    Late in 2002, after hundreds of stories on    this subject,        89    00:05:46.710 --> 00:05:51.030    I received a letter from a Father Thomas P.    Doyle.        90    00:05:51.030 --> 00:05:54.600    Father Doyle had struggled for years in vain        91    00:05:54.600 --> 00:05:59.610    to get the Church to confront the very issue    we were writing about.        92    00:05:59.610 --> 00:06:02.080    He expressed deep gratitude for our work.        93    00:06:02.080 --> 00:06:03.730    "It is momentous," he wrote,        94    00:06:03.730 --> 00:06:08.460    "and its good effects will reverberate for    decades."        95    00:06:08.460 --> 00:06:13.139    Father Doyle did not see journalists as the    enemy,        96    00:06:13.139 --> 00:06:17.470    he saw us as an ally when one was sorely needed.        97    00:06:17.470 --> 00:06:19.000    So did abuse survivors.        98    00:06:19.000 --> 00:06:22.310    I kept Father Doyle's letter on my desk,        99    00:06:22.310 --> 00:06:31.170    a daily reminder of what journalists must    do when we see evidence of wrongdoing.        100    00:06:31.170 --> 00:06:33.280    Harvard's commencement speaker two years ago,        101    00:06:33.280 --> 00:06:36.360    civil rights pioneer John Lewis once said    this,        102    00:06:36.360 --> 00:06:39.650    ''When you see something that is not right,        103    00:06:39.650 --> 00:06:43.510    not fair, not just, you have to speak up.        104    00:06:43.510 --> 00:06:45.280    You have to say something,        105    00:06:45.280 --> 00:06:48.660    you have to do something.''        106    00:06:48.660 --> 00:06:50.800    We as journalists have the capacity along    with        107    00:06:50.800 --> 00:06:54.560    the constitutional right to say and do something.        108    00:06:54.560 --> 00:06:57.180    We also have the obligation,        109    00:06:57.180 --> 00:07:00.200    and we must have the will.        110    00:07:00.200 --> 00:07:06.300    So must you. Every one of you has a stake    in this idea of free expression.        111    00:07:06.300 --> 00:07:08.770    You want to be free to express your views.        112    00:07:08.770 --> 00:07:10.840    You should be free to hear the views of others,        113    00:07:10.840 --> 00:07:12.919    the same or different.        114    00:07:12.919 --> 00:07:15.150    You want to be free to watch any movie,        115    00:07:15.150 --> 00:07:18.560    to read any book, to listen to any lyrics.        116    00:07:18.560 --> 00:07:25.860    You should be free to say what you know is    true WAS NOT A DISSIDENT.        71    00:04:53.479 --> 00:04:55.520    (speaking in German)        72    00:04:55.520 --> 00:04:59.400    I DIDN'T RUN UP AND BANG AGAINST    THE WALL.        73    00:04:59.400 --> 00:05:02.129    (speaking in German)        74    00:05:02.129 --> 00:05:06.600    NOR HOWEVER DID I DENY ITS    EXISTENCE, FOR I DIDN'T WANT TO        75    00:05:06.600 --> 00:05:09.020    LIE TO MYSELF.        76    00:05:09.020 --> 00:05:12.240    (speaking in German)        77    00:05:12.240 --> 00:05:14.939    THE BERLIN WALL LIMITED MY    OPPORTUNITIES.        78    00:05:14.939 --> 00:05:17.270    (speaking in German)        79    00:05:17.270 --> 00:05:22.199    IT QUITE LITERALLY STOOD IN MY    WAY.        80    00:05:22.199 --> 00:05:25.310    (speaking in German)        81    00:05:25.310 --> 00:05:29.210    HOWEVER, THERE WAS ONE THING,    WHICH THIS WALL COULDN'T DO        82    00:05:29.210 --> 00:05:31.660    DURING ALL OF THOSE YEARS.        83    00:05:31.660 --> 00:05:35.360    (speaking in German)        84    00:05:35.360 --> 00:05:39.540    IT COULDN'T IMPOSE LIMITS ON MY    INNER THOUGHTS.        85    00:05:39.540 --> 00:05:48.000    (speaking in German)        86    00:05:48.009 --> 00:05:53.420    MY PERSONALITY, MY IMAGINATION,    MY DREAMS AND DESIRES,        87    00:05:53.420 --> 00:05:59.070    PROHIBITIONS OR COERCION    COULDN'T LIMIT ANY OF THAT.        88    00:05:59.070 --> 00:06:00.070    (speaking in German)        89    00:06:00.070 --> 00:06:02.410    THEN CAME 1989.        90    00:06:02.410 --> 00:06:08.220    (speaking in German)        91    00:06:08.220 --> 00:06:11.830    A COMMON DESIRE FOR FREEDOM    UNLEASHED INCREDIBLE FORCES        92    00:06:11.830 --> 00:06:13.030    THROUGHOUT EUROPE.        93    00:06:13.030 --> 00:06:21.340    (speaking in German)        94    00:06:21.340 --> 00:06:27.360    IN POLAND, IN HUNGARY, IN CZECHOLSOVAKIA,    AS WELL AS IN EAST GERMANY HUNDREDS OF THOUSANDS        95    00:06:27.379 --> 00:06:30.100    OF PEOPLE DARED TO TAKE TO THE STREETS.        96    00:06:30.100 --> 00:06:33.830    (speaking in German)        97    00:06:33.830 --> 00:06:37.750    THE PEOPLE DEMONSTRATED AND    BROUGHT DOWN THE WALL.        98    00:06:37.750 --> 00:06:42.920    (speaking in German)        99    00:06:42.920 --> 00:06:46.770    SOMETHING, WHICH MANY PEOPLE    INCLUDING MYSELF WOULD NOT HAVE        100    00:06:46.770 --> 00:06:50.110    BELIEVED POSSIBLE BECAME REALITY.        101    00:06:50.110 --> 00:06:55.300    (speaking in German)        102    00:06:55.300 --> 00:07:00.759    WHERE THERE WAS ONCE ONLY A DARK    WALL, A DOOR SUDDENLY OPENED.        103    00:07:00.759 --> 00:07:03.150    (speaking in German)        104    00:07:03.150 --> 00:07:08.550    FOR ME, TOO, THE MOMENT HAD COME    TO WALK THROUGH THAT DOOR.        105    00:07:08.550 --> 00:07:12.479    (speaking in German)        106    00:07:12.479 --> 00:07:16.970    I NO LONGER HAD TO TURN AWAY    FROM FREEDOM AT THE LAST MINUTE.        107    00:07:16.970 --> 00:07:21.330    (speaking in German)        108    00:07:21.330 --> 00:07:25.880    I WAS ABLE TO CROSS THIS BORDER    AND VENTURE OUT INTO THE GREAT,        109    00:07:25.880 --> 00:07:27.480    WIDE OPEN.        110    00:07:27.480 --> 00:07:36.660    (speaking in German)        111    00:07:36.669 --> 00:07:41.280    DURING THESE MONTHS, 30 YEARS    AGO, I EXPERIENCED FIRST-HAND        112    00:07:41.280 --> 00:07:45.740    THAT NOTHING HAS TO STAY THE WAY IT IS.        113    00:07:45.740 --> 00:07:54.520    (speaking in German)        114    00:07:54.520 --> 00:07:58.569    THIS EXPERIENCE, DEAR GRADUATES,    IS THE FIRST THOUGHT I WANT TO        115    00:07:58.569 --> 00:08:01.510    SHARE WITH YOU TODAY FOR YOUR    FUTURE.        116    00:08:01.510 --> 00:08:07.199    (speaking in German)        117    00:08:07.199 --> 00:08:12.409    ANYTHING THAT SEEMS TO BE SET IN    STONE OR INALTERABLE CAN INDEED        118    00:08:12.409 --> 00:08:15.240    CHANGE.        119    00:08:16.800 --> 00:08:26.540    [APPLAUSE]        120    00:08:26.550 --> 00:08:31.569    (speaking in German)        121    00:08:31.569 --> 00:08:34.180    >> IN MATTERS BOTH LARGE AND SMALL,        122    00:08:34.180 --> 00:08:37.360    (speaking in German)        123    00:08:37.360 --> 00:08:40.810    IT HOLDS TRUE THAT EVERY    CHANGE BEGINS IN THE MIND.        124    00:08:40.810 --> 00:08:45.880    (speaking in German)        125    00:08:45.880 --> 00:08:48.290    MY PARENTS' GENERATION    DISCOVERED THIS IN A MOST        126    00:08:48.290 --> 00:08:50.760    PAINFUL WAY.        127    00:08:50.760 --> 00:08:55.220    (speaking in German)        128    00:08:55.230 --> 00:09:00.530    MY FATHER AND MOTHER WERE BORN    IN 1926 AND 1928.        129    00:09:00.530 --> 00:09:09.980    (speaking in German)        130    00:09:09.980 --> 00:09:13.840    WHEN THEY WERE AS OLD AS MOST OF    YOU HERE TODAY, THE BETRAYAL OF        131    00:09:13.840 --> 00:09:20.500    ALL CIVILIZED VALUES THAT    WORLD WAR II HAD JUST ENDED,        132    00:09:20.500 --> 00:09:26.710    (speaking in German)        133    00:09:26.710 --> 00:09:31.580    MY COUNTRY, GERMANY, HAD BROUGHT    UNIMAGINABLE SUFFERING ON EUROPE        134    00:09:31.580 --> 00:09:33.620    AND THE WORLD.        135    00:09:33.620 --> 00:09:40.480    (speaking in German)        136    00:09:40.480 --> 00:09:43.320    THE VICTORS AND THE DEFEATED    COULD EASILY HAVE REMAINED        137    00:09:43.320 --> 00:09:46.480    IRRECONCILABLE FOR MANY YEARS.        138    00:09:46.480 --> 00:09:50.940    (speaking in German)        139    00:09:50.940 --> 00:09:57.530    BUT INSTEAD, EUROPE OVERCAME    CENTURIES-OLD CONFLICTS.        140    00:09:57.530 --> 00:10:01.720    (speaking in German)        141    00:10:01.720 --> 00:10:09.530    A PEACEFUL ORDER BASED ON COMMON VALUES    RATHER THAN SUPPOSED NATIONAL STRENGTH EMERGED.        142    00:10:09.530 --> 00:10:19.450    (speaking in German)        143    00:10:19.450 --> 00:10:23.590    DESPITE ALL THE DISCUSSIONS AND    TEMPORARY SETBACKS, I FIRMLY        144    00:10:23.590 --> 00:10:28.620    BELIEVE THAT WE EUROPEANS HAVE    UNITED FOR THE BETTER.        145    00:10:28.620 --> 00:10:38.060    [APPLAUSE]        146    00:10:38.060 --> 00:10:47.640    (speaking in German)        147    00:10:47.640 --> 00:10:51.100    >> AND THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN    GERMANS AND AMERICANS TOO        148    00:10:51.100 --> 00:10:59.760    DEMONSTRATES HOW FORMER WARTIME    ENEMIES CAN BECOME FRIENDS.        149    00:10:59.760 --> 00:11:04.620    [APPLAUSE]        150    00:11:04.620 --> 00:11:14.790    (speaking in German)        151    00:11:14.790 --> 00:11:18.140    >> IT WAS GEORGE MARSHALL WHO    GAVE A CRUCIAL CONTRIBUTION TO        152    00:11:18.140 --> 00:11:22.520    THIS FOR THE PLAN HE ANNOUNCED    AT THE COMMENCEMENT CEREMONIES        153    00:11:22.520 --> 00:11:27.800    IN 1947 IN THIS VERY PLACE.        154    00:11:27.800 --> 00:11:33.940    [APPLAUSE]        155    00:11:33.940 --> 00:11:49.020    (speaking in German)        156    00:11:49.220 --> 00:11:54.080    >>THE TRANSATLANTIC PARTNERSHIP    BASED ON VALUES, SUCH AS        157    00:11:54.090 --> 00:11:58.940    DEMOCRACY 00:12:08.180    THAN 70 YEARS NOW.        160    00:12:08.180 --> 00:12:15.700    [APPLAUSE]        161    00:12:15.700 --> 00:12:29.720    (speaking in German)        162    00:12:29.720 --> 00:12:33.640    IT WILL NOT BE LONG    NOW BEFORE THE POLITICIANS OF MY        163    00:12:33.640 --> 00:12:37.430    GENERATION ARE NO LONGER THE    SUBJECT OF THE EXERCISING        164    00:12:37.430 --> 00:12:42.160    LEADERSHIP PROGRAM AND AT MOST    WILL BE DEALT WITH IN LEADERSHIP        165    00:12:42.160 --> 00:12:43.380    IN HISTORY.        166    00:12:43.380 --> 00:12:46.630    (speaking in German)        167    00:12:46.630 --> 00:12:50.810    HARVARD CLASS OF 2019,        168    00:12:50.810 --> 00:12:57.380    (speaking in German)        169    00:12:57.380 --> 00:13:01.410    YOUR GENERATION WILL BE FACED WITH    THE CHALLENGES OF THE 21st        170    00:13:01.410 --> 00:13:04.520    CENTURY IN THE COMING DECADES.        171    00:13:04.520 --> 00:13:09.450    (speaking in German)        172    00:13:09.450 --> 00:13:13.840    YOU ARE AMONG THOSE WHO WILL LEAD US INTO    THE FUTURE.        173    00:13:13.840 --> 00:13:21.770    (speaking in German)        174    00:13:21.770 --> 00:13:27.410    PROTECTIONISM AND TRADE CONFLICTS JEOPARDIZE    FREE INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND THUS THE VERY        175    00:13:44.380 --> 00:13:49.640    THE DIGITAL TRANSFORMATION    AFFECTS ALL FACETS OF OUR LIVES.        179    00:13:49.640 --> 00:13:52.780    (speaking in German)        180    00:13:52.790 -->
