FAMILY MEMBERS,        325    00:25:33.940 --> 00:25:39.730    (speaking in German)        326    00:25:39.730 --> 00:25:45.240    AS WELL AS BETWEEN GROUPS WITHIN THE SOCIETY,    BETWEEN PEOPLE OF DIFFERENT SKIN COLORS,        327    00:25:45.240 --> 00:25:46.960    NATIONS AND RELIGIONS.        328    00:25:46.970 --> 00:25:51.130    (speaking in German)        329    00:25:51.130 --> 00:25:55.160    I WOULD LIKE US TO SEE BREAK DOWN THESE WALLS.        330    00:25:55.160 --> 00:26:03.610    [APPLAUSE]        331    00:26:04.800 --> 00:26:13.660    (speaking in German)        332    00:26:13.660 --> 00:26:20.230    WALLS THAT KEEP PREVENTING US FROM ENVISIONING THE WORLD IN WHICH, TOGETHER, WE WANT TO LIVE.        333    00:26:20.230 --> 00:26:22.800    (speaking in German)        334    00:26:22.800 --> 00:26:25.900    WHETHER WE MANAGE TO DO THAT IS    UP TO US.        335    00:26:25.900 --> 00:26:29.460    (speaking in German)        336    00:26:29.460 --> 00:26:34.210    THAT'S WHY MY FOURTH THOUGHT FOR YOU, DEAR    GRADUATES, TO CONSIDER IS THIS:        337    00:26:34.210 --> 00:26:37.020    (speaking in German)        338    00:26:37.020 --> 00:26:39.910    NOTHING CAN BE TAKEN FOR GRANTED.        339    00:26:39.910 --> 00:26:43.260    (speaking in German)        340    00:26:43.260 --> 00:26:46.030    OUR INDIVIDUAL LIBERTIES ARE NOT GIVENS.        341    00:26:46.030 --> 00:26:48.430    (speaking in German)        342    00:26:48.430 --> 00:26:51.450    DEMOCRACY IS NOT SOMETHING     WE CAN TAKE FOR GRANTED.        343    00:26:51.450 --> 00:26:53.400    (speaking in German)        344    00:26:53.400 --> 00:26:54.750    NEITHER IS PEACE.        345    00:26:54.750 --> 00:26:56.500    (speaking in German)        346    00:26:56.500 --> 00:26:59.030    AND NEITHER IS PROSPERITY.        347    00:26:59.030 --> 00:27:02.970    (speaking in German)        348    00:27:02.970 --> 00:27:07.080    BUT IF WE BREAK DOWN THE WALLS     THAT HEM US IN,        349    00:27:07.080 --> 00:27:09.880    (speaking in German)        350    00:27:10.800 --> 00:27:13.200    IF WE STEP OUT INTO THE OPEN AND HAVE        351    00:27:13.200 --> 00:27:16.280    THE COURAGE TO EMBRACE NEW BEGINNINGS,        352    00:27:16.460 --> 00:27:18.520    (speaking in German)        353    00:27:18.520 --> 00:27:19.440    EVERYTHING IS        354    00:27:19.440 --> 00:27:21.240    POSSIBLE.        355    00:27:21.240 --> 00:27:31.580    [APPLAUSE]        356    00:27:31.580 --> 00:27:33.540    (speaking in German)        357    00:27:33.540 --> 00:27:35.480    WALLS CAN COLLAPSE.        358    00:27:35.480 --> 00:27:37.440    (speaking in German)        359    00:27:37.440 --> 00:27:39.100    DICTATORSHIPS CAN DISAPPEAR.        360    00:27:39.680 --> 00:27:41.380    (speaking in German)        361    00:27:41.390 --> 00:27:43.380    WE CAN HALT GLOBAL WARMING.        362    00:27:43.380 --> 00:27:45.160    (speaking in German)        363    00:27:45.160 --> 00:27:47.260    WE CAN ERADICATE STARVATION.        364    00:27:47.260 --> 00:27:49.850    (speaking in German)        365    00:27:49.850 --> 00:27:52.500    WE CAN ELIMINATE DISEASES.        366    00:27:52.500 --> 00:27:56.720    (speaking in German)        367    00:27:56.720 --> 00:27:59.640    WE CAN GIVE PEOPLE, ESPECIALLY    GIRLS, ACCESS        368    00:27:59.640 --> 00:28:01.440    TO EDUCATION.        369    00:28:01.440 --> 00:28:08.660    [APPLAUSE]        370    00:28:08.900 --> 00:28:12.780    (speaking in German)        371    00:28:12.920 --> 00:28:16.080    WE CAN FIGHT THE CAUSES OF    DISPLACEMENT AND FORCED        372    00:28:16.080 --> 00:28:17.080    MIGRATION.        373    00:28:17.080 --> 00:28:19.380    (speaking in German)        374    00:28:19.380 --> 00:28:22.480    WE CAN DO ALL OF THAT.        375    00:28:22.480 --> 00:28:28.820    [APPLAUSE]        376    00:28:29.040 --> 00:28:39.720    (speaking in German)        377    00:28:39.720 --> 00:28:43.680    SO LET'S NOT START BY ASKING    WHAT ISN'T POSSIBLE OR FOCUSING        378    00:28:43.680 --> 00:28:45.440    ON WHAT HAS ALWAYS BEEN THAT    WAY.        379    00:28:45.800 --> 00:28:49.679    LET'S START BY ASKING WHAT IS    POSSIBLE AND LOOKING FOR THINGS        380    00:28:49.679 --> 00:28:52.540    THAT HAVE NEVER BEEN DONE LIKE    THAT BEFORE.        381    00:28:52.540 --> 00:29:07.020    (speaking in German)        382    00:29:07.020 --> 00:29:12.220    THIS IS EXACTLY WHAT I SAID TO    THE BUNDESTAG, THE GERMAN PARLIAMENT IN 2005        383    00:29:12.380 --> 00:29:16.700    IN MY FIRST POLICY STATEMENT AS    NEWLY ELECTED CHANCELLOR OF THE        384    00:29:16.710 --> 00:29:20.480    FEDERAL REPUBLIC OF GERMANY AND    THE FIRST WOMAN TO HOLD THIS        385    00:29:20.480 --> 00:29:21.660    OFFICE.        386    00:29:21.660 --> 00:29:30.740    [APPLAUSE]        387    00:29:31.000 --> 00:29:35.580    (speaking in German)        388    00:29:35.580 --> 00:29:39.100    AND I WANT TO USE PRECISELY    THESE WORDS TO SHARE WITH YOU MY        389    00:29:39.100 --> 00:29:40.530    FIFTH THOUGHT.        390    00:29:41.100 --> 00:29:43.900    (speaking in German)        391    00:29:43.900 --> 00:29:47.920    LET US SURPRISE OURSELVES BY    SHOWING WHAT IS POSSIBLE.        392    00:29:48.020 --> 00:29:50.600    (speaking in German)        393    00:29:50.600 --> 00:29:55.480    LET US SURPRISE OURSELVES BY    SHOWING WHAT WE ARE CAPABLE OF.        394    00:29:55.480 --> 00:30:03.340    (speaking in German)        395    00:30:03.340 --> 00:30:07.100    IN MY OWN LIFE, IT WAS THE FALL    OF THE BERLIN WALL THAT ALLOWED        396    00:30:07.100 --> 00:30:12.040    ME ALMOST 30 YEARS AGO TO STEP    OUT INTO THE OPEN.        397    00:30:12.040 --> 00:30:17.330    (speaking in German)        398    00:30:17.330 --> 00:30:21.020    AT THAT POINT, I LEFT MY WORK AS    A SCIENTIST BEHIND ME AND        399    00:30:21.020 --> 00:30:22.660    ENTERED POLITICS.        400    00:30:22.660 --> 00:30:25.720    (speaking in German)        401    00:30:25.720 --> 00:30:29.470    THAT WAS AN EXCITING AND MAGICAL    TIME.        402    00:30:29.470 --> 00:30:34.179    (speaking in German)        403    00:30:34.180 --> 00:30:38.490    JUST AS YOUR LIVES WILL BE     EXCITING AND MAGICAL.        404    00:30:39.060 --> 00:30:42.320    (speaking in German)        405    00:30:42.320 --> 00:30:45.860    BUT I ALSO EXPERIENCE MOMENTS OF    DOUBT AND WORRY.        406    00:30:46.680 --> 00:30:52.200    (speaking in German)        407    00:30:52.200 --> 00:30:58.900    FOR AT THAT TIME, WE ALL KNEW WHAT LAY BEHIND    US, BUT NOT WHAT MIGHT LIE AHEAD.        408    00:30:58.900 --> 00:31:04.400    (speaking in German)        409    00:31:04.400 --> 00:31:07.980    PERHAPS THAT REFLECTS A LITTLE    HOW YOU, TOO, ARE FEELING TODAY,        410    00:31:08.420 --> 00:31:12.580    AMIDST ALL THE JOY OF THIS    OCCASION.        411    00:31:12.580 --> 00:31:16.260    (speaking in German)        412    00:31:17.200 --> 00:31:23.860    THE SIXTH THOUGHT, I ALSO WANT    TO SHARE WITH YOU IS THIS:        413    00:31:23.860 --> 00:31:28.960    (speaking in German)        414    00:31:28.970 --> 00:31:33.490    THE MOMENT WHEN YOU STEP OUT    INTO THE OPEN IS ALSO A MOMENT        415    00:31:33.490 --> 00:31:35.240    OF RISK TAKING.        416    00:31:35.240 --> 00:31:40.380    (speaking in German)        417    00:31:40.380 --> 00:31:44.860    LETTING GO OF THE OLD IS PART OF    A NEW BEGINNING.        418    00:31:44.860 --> 00:31:48.010    (speaking in German)        419    00:31:48.010 --> 00:31:50.809    THERE IS NO BEGINNING WITHOUT AN END.        420    00:31:50.809 --> 00:31:52.559    (speaking in German)        421    00:31:52.559 --> 00:31:54.210    NO DAY WITHOUT NIGHT.        422    00:31:54.210 --> 00:31:56.720    (speaking in German)        423    00:31:56.720 --> 00:31:58.940    NO LIFE WITHOUT DEATH.        424    00:31:58.940 --> 00:32:06.620    (speaking in German)        425    00:32:06.620 --> 00:32:10.880    OUR WHOLE LIFE CONSISTS OF THE    DIFFERENCE, THE SPACE BETWEEN        426    00:32:10.880 --> 00:32:13.460    BEGINNING AND ENDING.        427    00:32:13.460 --> 00:32:18.680    (speaking in German)        428    00:32:18.680 --> 00:32:24.400    IT IS WHAT LIES IN BETWEEN THAT    WE CALL LIFE AND EXPERIENCE.        429    00:32:24.400 --> 00:32:34.960    (speaking in German)        430    00:32:34.960 --> 00:32:38.750    I BELIEVE THAT TIME AND TIME    AGAIN, WE NEED TO BE PREPARED TO        431    00:32:38.750 --> 00:32:44.300    KEEP BRINGING THINGS TO AN END IN ORDER TO    FEEL THE MAGIC OF NEW BEGINNINGS AND TO MAKE        432    00:32:44.300 --> 00:32:46.380    THE MOST OF OPPORTUNITIES.        433    00:32:46.900 --> 00:32:49.440    (speaking in German)        434    00:32:49.440 --> 00:32:51.620    THAT WAS WHAT I LEARNED AS A STUDENT,        435    00:32:51.620 --> 00:32:52.740    (speaking in German)        436    00:32:52.740 --> 00:32:54.000    AS A    SCIENTIST,        437    00:32:54.000 --> 00:32:55.740    (speaking in German)        438    00:32:55.960 --> 00:32:57.540    AND IT IS WHAT I EXPERIENCE NOW        439    00:32:57.540 --> 00:32:59.530    IN POLITICS.        440    00:32:59.530 --> 00:33:02.840    (speaking in German)        441    00:33:02.840 --> 00:33:06.090    AND WHO KNOWS WHAT LIFE WILL BRING AFTER MY    TIME AS A POLITICIAN?        442    00:33:06.620 --> 00:33:07.780    (speaking in German)        443    00:33:07.780 --> 00:33:10.160    THAT, TOO, IS COMPLETELY OPEN.        444    00:33:10.740 --> 00:33:12.140    (speaking in German)        445    00:33:12.140 --> 00:33:13.880    ONLY ONE THING IS CLEAR.        446    00:33:13.880 --> 00:33:16.620    (speaking in German)        447    00:33:16.620 --> 00:33:20.240    IT WILL AGAIN BE SOMETHING    DIFFERENT AND SOMETHING NEW.        448    00:33:21.540 --> 00:33:24.640    (speaking in English) >>     THAT'S WHY I WANT TO LEAVE    THIS WISH WITH YOU:        449    00:33:25.680 --> 00:33:30.620    TEAR DOWN WALLS OF IGNORANCE AND    NARROW-MINDEDNESS, FOR NOTHING        450    00:33:30.620 --> 00:33:33.060    HAS TO STAY AS IT IS.        451    00:33:33.060 --> 00:33:51.000    [APPLAUSE]        452    00:33:51.480 --> 00:33:53.100    IT'S SIX THINGS        453    00:33:53.260 --> 00:33:58.620    TAKE JOINT ACTION IN THE    INTERESTS OF THE MULTILATERAL        454    00:33:58.620 --> 00:34:00.820    GLOBAL WORLD.        455    00:34:02.140 --> 00:34:07.390    KEEP ASKING YOURSELVES AM I    DOING SOMETHING BECAUSE IT IS        456    00:34:07.390 --> 00:34:10.720    RIGHT OR SIMPLY BECAUSE IT'S    POSSIBLE?        457    00:34:12.419 --> 00:34:16.729    DON'T FORGET THAT FREEDOM IS    NEVER SOMETHING THAT CAN BE        458    00:34:16.729 --> 00:34:18.160    TAKEN FOR GRANTED.        459    00:34:19.380 --> 00:34:22.659    SURPRISE YOURSELF WITH WHAT IS    POSSIBLE.        460    00:34:24.520 --> 00:34:28.500    REMEMBER THAT OPENNESS ALWAYS    INVOLVES RISKS.        461    00:34:29.420 --> 00:34:33.019    LETTING GO OF THE OLD IS PART OF    THE NEW BEGINNING.        462    00:34:34.369 --> 00:34:39.909    AND ABOVE ALL, NOTHING CAN BE    TAKEN FOR GRANTED, EVERYTHING IS        463    00:34:39.909 --> 00:34:40.900    POSSIBLE.        464    00:34:41.900 --> 00:34:42.900    THANK YOU.

title: Graduate English address by Lucila Takjerad | Harvard Commencement 2019
desc: Graduate English speaker Lucila Takjerad addresses fellow students in the Class of 2019 at Harvard's Commencement ceremonies on May 30, 2019.
speech_raw: 1    00:00:00.089 --> 00:00:08.340    As Harvard graduates you will be asked    to go into the world and do the most you        2    00:00:08.340 --> 00:00:09.500    can do.        3    00:00:10.360 --> 00:00:13.780    I am here to ask you to do        4    00:00:13.780 --> 00:00:16.800    the least.        5    00:00:19.060 --> 00:00:21.060    [LAUGHING]        6    00:00:23.300 --> 00:00:26.160    I grew up in a small village in        7    00:00:26.160 --> 00:00:27.220    Algeria.        8    00:00:28.340 --> 00:00:33.380    Every Friday my sister and I had our        9    00:00:33.390 --> 00:00:37.960    weekly shower at the public bath.        10    00:00:37.960 --> 00:00:40.620    We didn't have running water at home.        11    00:00:41.800 --> 00:00:46.880    On winter nights we cuddled against the    cold        12    00:00:47.280 --> 00:00:50.780    because our heat was cut off.        13    00:00:51.820 --> 00:01:00.160    And on Sundays, we hid our hunger in order not    to worry our parents.        14    00:01:03.060 --> 00:01:05.500    When I was seven years old        15    00:01:05.500 --> 00:01:10.160    my country plunged into a    bloody civil war.        16    00:01:11.500 --> 00:01:14.120    Every night I pray to        17    00:01:14.120 --> 00:01:22.540    God that tomorrow there would not be an    empty seat at our dinner table.        18    00:01:24.720 --> 00:01:35.100    On one hot summer day in 1994 my life was    changed forever by men whom I never met        19    00:01:35.100 --> 00:01:39.020    do not know and can never thank.        20    00:01:41.300 --> 00:01:45.479    My mother was at the local market when she        21    00:01:45.479 --> 00:01:50.540    noticed a chaotic gathering        22    00:01:50.540 --> 00:01:55.409    wading into    the crowd she learned that the French        23    00:01:55.409 --> 00:02:01.800    government was allowing some Algerians    to find refuge from war.        24    00:02:02.820 --> 00:02:04.079    All you had to        25    00:02:04.080 --> 00:02:07.740    do was write your name on a list.        26    00:02:08.600 --> 00:02:12.440    My mother desperately wanted to sign that        27    00:02:12.450 --> 00:02:15.120    list. That list        28    00:02:15.120 --> 00:02:17.769    might promise her daughters a        29    00:02:17.769 --> 00:02:19.460    better future.        30    00:02:21.620 --> 00:02:25.800    But there was one problem:        31    00:02:25.800 --> 00:02:29.540    My mother was illiterate.        32    00:02:30.720 --> 00:02:31.560    She did not        33    00:02:31.560 --> 00:02:39.640    know how to write her name - Favilla Takjerad.        34    00:02:39.640 --> 00:02:43.640    Dejected, she walked away.        35    00:02:46.780 --> 00:02:50.880    A man noticed her and ran after her.        36    00:02:50.880 --> 00:02:54.620    He got my mother's name and wrote it        37    00:02:54.640 --> 00:02:56.920    down on the list.        38    00:02:58.000 --> 00:03:02.080    [APPLAUSE]        39    00:03:02.620 --> 00:03:05.520    A few months later        40    00:03:05.520 --> 00:03:09.960    my family was fortunate to emigrate to        41    00:03:09.960 --> 00:03:10.740    France.        42    00:03:13.520 --> 00:03:18.620    I was sad to leave my beloved    homeland,        43    00:03:18.620 --> 00:03:20.540    caring neighbors,        44    00:03:20.640 --> 00:03:24.720    childhood friends and extended family.        45    00:03:24.720 --> 00:03:26.820    But I knew that        46    00:03:26.940 --> 00:03:29.760    bright opportunities awaited me.        47    00:03:31.000 --> 00:03:32.920    Had I stayed in my village,        48    00:03:33.420 --> 00:03:38.820    assuming I was spared from bullets or bombs,        49    00:03:38.820 --> 00:03:40.900    My life would have been very different.        50    00:03:42.280 --> 00:03:45.060    I would not have become the first woman in my        51    00:03:45.069 --> 00:03:48.060    family to graduate from college,        52    00:03:48.060 --> 00:03:50.330    to work and live abroad.        53    00:03:51.140 --> 00:03:52.599    I would not have had the        54    00:03:52.600 --> 00:04:00.300    chance to call Harvard my home this past year.        55    00:04:00.300 --> 00:04:04.200    As we are graduating today I still        56    00:04:04.200 --> 00:04:06.920    find myself asking        57    00:04:06.920 --> 00:04:12.980    why did this    wonderful man run after my mother?        58    00:04:12.980 --> 00:04:21.720    A simple gesture of writing a stranger's    name on a page offered an entire family        59    00:04:21.720 --> 00:04:25.060    hope for a better life.        60    00:04:25.440 --> 00:04:27.320    He will probably never know the        61    00:04:27.320 --> 00:04:28.960    difference he made        62    00:04:28.960 --> 00:04:33.700    but from the small    seeds of his goodness        63    00:04:33.700 --> 00:04:35.630    have grown fruits        64    00:04:35.630 --> 00:04:37.380    of prosperity        65    00:04:37.380 --> 00:04:39.020    for my family        66    00:04:39.020 --> 00:04:40.380    myself        67    00:04:40.380 --> 00:04:43.300    and everyone who we touch.        68    00:04:44.340 --> 00:04:46.020    I now have the        69    00:04:46.020 --> 00:04:49.800    ability to shape my world.        70    00:04:49.800 --> 00:04:54.200    But this ability was sparked by one        71    00:04:54.200 --> 00:04:59.840    little encounter which lit up the course    of my life.        72    00:05:01.280 --> 00:05:04.580    So that is the real power,        73    00:05:04.580 --> 00:05:07.520    the power of little things.        74    00:05:07.520 --> 00:05:10.160    The least you can do        75    00:05:10.160 --> 00:05:13.380    can bring true change.        76    00:05:14.720 --> 00:05:16.880    Perhaps        77    00:05:16.880 --> 00:05:19.640    you have been blessed in your lives        78    00:05:19.640 --> 00:05:25.060    with small gifts that made big changes.        79    00:05:25.060 --> 00:05:31.020    Maybe it was a teacher who instilled in you    her love of a certain subject        80    00:05:31.200 --> 00:05:37.000    Or a kind stranger who helped you with directions    when you are lost.        81    00:05:37.000 --> 00:05:40.180    At Harvard I see it        82    00:05:40.180 --> 00:05:47.270    every day in the smiles of the cafeteria    staff who keep me so well        83    00:05:47.270 --> 00:05:49.740    caffeinated.        84    00:05:50.500 --> 00:05:56.860    And in ad-hoc babysitting    circles, small things,        85    00:05:56.860 --> 00:06:00.660    such small things.        86    00:06:01.380 --> 00:06:05.820    But from these small things grow    inspired people,        87    00:06:05.820 --> 00:06:08.780    lasting friendships and        88    00:06:08.780 --> 00:06:12.220    stronger communities.        89    00:06:13.460 --> 00:06:18.500    When one person    thanks another the second person often        90    00:06:18.500 --> 00:06:22.980    replies, oh, it's the least they can do        91    00:06:22.980 --> 00:06:29.150    because often the least you can do can        92    00:06:29.150 --> 00:06:31.080    can be more than enough.        93    00:06:31.080 --> 00:06:33.680    You don't need to    move mountains        94    00:06:33.680 --> 00:06:35.340    maybe it's a matter of        95    00:06:35.350 --> 00:06:39.510    translating documents for a family at    immigration office who        96    00:06:39.510 --> 00:06:42.360    or offering a car ride        97    00:06:42.360 --> 00:06:44.820    to a pregnant lady.        98    00:06:44.820 --> 00:06:49.600    You never know    how these small gestures can affect        99    00:06:49.600 --> 00:06:50.860    people's lives.        100    00:06:52.040 --> 00:06:58.080    But I can tell you, they    do.        101    00:06:58.080 --> 00:07:02.260    Fellow graduates, of course do the        102    00:07:02.270 --> 00:07:03.880    most you can do.        103    00:07:03.880 --> 00:07:08.500    Your education and    legacy demand it.        104    00:07:08.500 --> 00:07:10.040    But also        105    00:07:10.400 --> 00:07:12.640    do the least you can do.        106    00:07:12.640 --> 00:07:17.940    Because the least we can do    might turn out to be the most        107    00:07:17.940 --> 00:07:19.100    significant.        108    00:07:21.040 --> 00:07:24.800    And to that gentleman in Algeria,        109    00:07:24.800 --> 00:07:26.220    I now say        110    00:07:26.229 --> 00:07:30.180    (speaking Algerian)        111    00:07:30.180 --> 00:07:33.856    Thank you and    God bless you.        112    00:07:33.860 --> 00:07:37.270    And to each of you today        113    00:07:37.270 --> 00:07:40.120    I ask of you:        114    00:07:40.120 --> 00:07:43.260    what is the least you can do        115    00:07:43.260 --> 00:07:46.720    now to make the world around you a        116    00:07:46.720 --> 00:07:50.160    little better.        117    00:07:51.160 --> 00:07:56.540    [APPLAUSE]

title: Address by Harvard President Larry Bacow | Harvard Commencement 2019
desc: Harvard President Larry Bacow addresses the Class of 2019 at Harvard's Commencement ceremonies on May 30, 2019.
speech_raw: 1    00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:01.960    [APPLAUSE]        2    00:00:03.889 --> 00:00:05.910    >> THANK YOU VERY MUCH MARGARET    FOR THAT VERY GENEROUS        3    00:00:05.910 --> 00:00:07.509    INTRODUCTION.        4    00:00:07.509 --> 00:00:10.780    FIRST LET ME SAY CONGRATULATIONS    TO OUR GRADUATES.        5    00:00:10.780 --> 00:00:14.100    WELCOME BACK TO OUR ALUMNI, GOOD    AFTERNOON, TO EVERYONE,        6    00:00:14.100 --> 00:00:16.630    COLLEAGUES AND FRIENDS AND    FAMILY MEMBERS.        7    00:00:16.630 --> 00:00:22.770    LOVED ONES, AND OUR MOST SPECIAL    GUESTS, OUR EMINENT SPEAKER.        8    00:00:22.770 --> 00:00:25.519    IT'S A PLEASURE TO ADDRESS YOU    THIS AFTERNOON AND TO OFFER A        9    00:00:25.519 --> 00:00:28.759    FEW REFLECTIONS AS I APPROACH    THE END OF MY FIRST YEAR AS        10    00:00:28.759 --> 00:00:29.759    PRESIDENT.        11    00:00:29.759 --> 00:00:32.400    I REALIZE, HOWEVER, THAT I'M    LITERALLY THE LAST THING        12    00:00:32.400 --> 00:00:36.120    STANDING BETWEEN YOU AND THE    SPEECH THAT YOU'VE ALL ACTUALLY        13    00:00:36.120 --> 00:00:38.230    COME HERE TO HEAR.        14    00:00:38.230 --> 00:00:43.230    SO WHILE I CAN'T PROMISE TO BE    MESMERIZINGLY ELOQUENT, I CAN AT        15    00:00:43.230 --> 00:00:47.079    LEAST PROMISE TO BE MERCIFULLY    BRIEF.        16    00:00:47.079 --> 00:00:49.801    WE GATHER THIS AFTERNOON, BUOYED    BY THE ASPIRATIONS OF OUR        17    00:00:49.801 --> 00:00:50.829    GRADUATES.        18    00:00:50.829 --> 00:00:54.719    SOME 7,100 PEOPLE WHO HAVE    DISTINGUISHED THEMSELVES IN        19    00:00:54.719 --> 00:00:58.440    NEARLY EVERY FIELD AND EVERY    DISCIPLINE IMAGINABLE.        20    00:00:58.440 --> 00:01:02.879    WE WELCOME THEM INTO THE    VENERABLE RANKS OF OUR ALUMNI        21    00:01:02.879 --> 00:01:07.210    AND WE SEND THEM FORTH INTO    OWORLD THAT IS VERY MUCH IN NEED        22    00:01:07.210 --> 00:01:10.680    OF BOTH THEIR MINDS AND THEIR    HEARTS.        23    00:01:10.680 --> 00:01:15.880    DURING MY BRIEF TIME IN OFFICE,    OUR WORLD HAS REMINDED US DAILY        24    00:01:15.880 --> 00:01:20.700    OF THE NECESSITY AND THE URGENCY    OF OUR WORK.        25    00:01:20.700 --> 00:01:23.270    WE'VE WITNESSED THE COARSENING    OF PUBLIC DISCOURSE AND THE        26    00:01:23.270 --> 00:01:27.370    VOLATILITY OF NATIONAL AND    INTERNATIONAL AFFAIRS.        27    00:01:27.370 --> 00:01:31.200    WE'VE MOURNED WHEN GUN VIOLENCE    HAS CUT FUTURES SHORT AND        28    00:01:31.200 --> 00:01:34.990    GATHERINGS OF THE FAITHFUL,    JEWISH, MUSLIM AND CHRISTIAN        29    00:01:34.990 --> 00:01:37.579    HAVE ENDED IN BLOODSHED.        30    00:01:37.579 --> 00:01:41.300    WE'VE CONTINUED TO CONFRONT THE    EXISTENTIAL THREAT POSED BY        31    00:01:41.300 --> 00:01:45.340    CLIMATE CHANGE AND WE'VE REELED    AS EXTREME WEATHER HAS DESTROYED        32    00:01:45.340 --> 00:01:48.649    HOMES AND CLAIMED LIVES.        33    00:01:48.649 --> 00:01:51.680    AND WE'VE GROWN INCREASINGLY    AWARE OF THE SCOURGE OF SEXUAL        34    00:01:51.680 --> 00:01:55.390    HARASSMENT AND SEXUAL ASSAULT    AND HAVE STRUGGLED TO CONSIDER        35    00:01:55.390 --> 00:01:59.439    HOW INSTITUTIONS, HARVARD AMONG    THEM, CAN PREVENT AND ADDRESS        36    00:01:59.439 --> 00:02:03.200    BEHAVIOR THAT THREATENS    INDIVIDUALS AND WEAKENS        37    00:02:03.200 --> 00:02:04.990    COMMUNITIES.        38    00:02:04.990 --> 00:02:09.820    TO BE SURE THERE IS MUCH IN THIS    WORLD THAT RIGHTLY TROUBLES US.        39    00:02:09.820 --> 00:02:15.090    BUT THERE'S EVEN MORE THAT GIVES    US CAUSE FOR HOPE.        40    00:02:15.090 --> 00:02:18.290    IT'S THAT SPIRIT OF HOPE, THE    WILLINGNESS BOTH TO SEE THE        41    00:02:18.290 --> 00:02:23.650    WORLD AS IT IS AND TO CONSIDER    HOW WE CAN HELP MAKE IT BETTER        42    00:02:23.650 --> 00:02:28.150    THAT IS IN MANY WAYS THE SPIRIT    THAT DEFINES THIS UNIVERSITY AND        43    00:02:28.150 --> 00:02:32.060    I BELIEVE JOINS US ALL TOGETHER.        44    00:02:32.060 --> 00:02:36.030    SINCE I TOOK OFFICE ON JULY 1,    I'VE SEEN THE VALUE OF BOTH        45    00:02:36.030 --> 00:02:38.940    KNOWLEDGE AND EDUCATION AT WORK    IN THE WORLD.        46    00:02:38.940 --> 00:02:42.650    I'VE SEEN THE GOOD BEING DONE BY    OUR FACULTY AND OUR STUDENTS, BY        47    00:02:42.650 --> 00:02:45.850    OUR ALUMNI AND OUR STAFF AND OUR    FRIENDS AND I'VE SEEN        48    00:02:45.850 --> 00:02:50.870    EXPRESSIONS OF COMPASSION AND    PATIENCE AND KINDNESS AND WISDOM        49    00:02:50.870 --> 00:02:52.970    THAT HAVE MOVED ME DEEPLY.        50    00:02:52.970 --> 00:02:55.490    I HAD THE BRIDGE OF HELPING TO    CELEBRATE MEMBERS OF OUR        51    00:02:55.490 --> 00:02:59.030    COMMUNITY WHO WERE RECENTLY    SWORN IN AS NEW UNITED STATES        52    00:02:59.030 --> 00:03:00.600    CITIZENS.        53    00:03:00.600 --> 00:03:04.190    GRADUATES OF THE HARVARD BRIDGE    PROGRAM, THROUGH THEIR OWN HARD        54    00:03:04.190 --> 00:03:07.849    WORK AND WITH THE GENEROUS HELP    OF VOLUNTEER STUDENT AND YOUHAM        55    00:03:07.849 --> 00:03:11.610    MY TUTORS THEY CAN NOW ENJOY THE    FULL RIGHTS AND PRIVILEGES OF        56    00:03:11.610 --> 00:03:17.230    CITIZENSHIP AND THE FULL SENSE    OF BELONGING THAT COMES WITH IT.        57    00:03:17.230 --> 00:03:20.360    IT WAS TRULY AN INSPIRING    CEREMONY.        58    00:03:20.360 --> 00:03:23.299    AT A TIME WHEN SO MANY PEOPLE    ARE DISPIRITED BY THE DEEP        59    00:03:23.299 --> 00:03:26.930    DIVISIONS IN OUR COUNTRY, WHEN    OUR POLITICS SEEM SO        60    00:03:26.930 --> 00:03:30.939    DYSFUNCTIONAL, OUR GRADUATES ARE    TAKING UP THE CAUSE OF PUBLIC        61    00:03:30.939 --> 00:03:35.060    SERVICE BY RUNNING FOR OFFICE IN    RECORD NUMBERS.        62    00:03:35.060 --> 00:03:40.150    THE WORLD NEEDS THEM AND THEIR    WILLINGNESS TO SERVE GIVES ME        63    00:03:40.150 --> 00:03:45.319    HOPE.        64    00:03:45.319 --> 00:03:51.990    [APPLAUSE]    AS MARGARET NOTED THIS PAST YEAR        65    00:03:51.990 --> 00:03:54.340    I TRAVELED TO MEET ALUMNI WHO    ARE HELPING TO STRENGTHEN        66    00:03:54.340 --> 00:03:58.250    COMMUNITIES IN DETROIT AND    DALLAS AND HOUSTON.        67    00:03:58.250 --> 00:04:01.040    IN MIAMI, PHOENIX AND NEW YORK.        68    00:04:01.040 --> 00:04:05.720    IN LOS ANGELES, SAN FRANCISCO,    AND SAN DIEGO; IN CHINA, JAPAN        69    00:04:05.720 --> 00:04:06.730    AND ENGLAND.        70    00:04:06.730 --> 00:04:08.849    PEOPLE WHO ARE NOT ONLY    LAUNCHING AND BUILDING        71    00:04:08.849 --> 00:04:11.819    BUSINESSES AND CREATING    OPPORTUNITY, BUT PEOPLE WHO ARE        72    00:04:11.819 --> 00:04:17.079    ALSO TEACHING, VOLUNTEERING,    ADVANCING IMPORTANT LEGISLATION,        73    00:04:17.079 --> 00:04:20.570    WORKING FOR NONPROFITS, AND    SERVING THE PUBLIC GOOD.        74    00:04:20.570 --> 00:04:24.660    I HAVE YET TO MEET ANYONE WHO    THINKS THAT THIS WORLD THAT WE        75    00:04:24.660 --> 00:04:26.700    LIVE IN IS PERFECT.        76    00:04:26.700 --> 00:04:29.130    THIS IS NOT A POLITICAL    STATEMENT.        77    00:04:29.130 --> 00:04:33.400    IT'S EQUALLY TRUE OF LIBERALS    AND CONSERVATIVES, DEMOCRATS AND        78    00:04:33.400 --> 00:04:34.400    REPUBLICANS.        79    00:04:34.400 --> 00:04:38.000    AND IF YOU DON'T THINK THE WORLD    THAT WE LIVE IN IS PERFECT, THE        80    00:04:38.000 --> 00:04:44.070    ONLY WAY IT GETS BETTER IS IF    GOOD PEOPLE WORK TO REPAIR IT.        81    00:04:44.070 --> 00:04:49.050    OUR STUDENTS, OUR FACULTY, OUR    STAFF AND ALUMNI ARE DOING THAT        82    00:04:49.050 --> 00:04:52.220    DAILY AND IT MAKES ME SO PROUD.        83    00:04:52.220 --> 00:04:56.620    THIS YEAR I HAD THE PRIVILEGE TO    MEET AND TO BE MOVED BY NOT JUST        84    00:04:56.620 --> 00:05:01.490    ONE, BUT TWO OF THE NATION'S    PREEMINENT POETS, THE UNITED        85    00:05:01.490 --> 00:05:07.620    STATES YOUTH POET LAUREATE, OUR    OWN AMANDA AND THE UNITED STATES        86    00:05:07.620 --> 00:05:14.490    POET LAUREATE OUR OWN TRACY K.    SMITH.        87    00:05:14.490 --> 00:05:21.660    [APPLAUSE]    I HAVE ALSO HAD THE CHANCE TO        88    00:05:21.660 --> 00:05:26.570    MARVEL AT ARTISTS WHO EVERY DAY    BREATHE LIFE INTO OUR CAMPUS        89    00:05:26.570 --> 00:05:30.910    WITH THEIR PERFORMANCES AND    THEIR CREATIVE WORK.        90    00:05:30.910 --> 00:05:34.910    IT'S AMAZING TO SEE THE TALENT    THAT IS REPRESENTED ON THIS        91    00:05:34.910 --> 00:05:40.310    CAMPUS AND AMONG OUR ALUMNI, OUR    FACULTY AND STAFF.        92    00:05:40.310 --> 00:05:45.250    AND EVERY DAY I'VE LEARNED MORE    ABOUT THE REMARKABLE EFFORTS OF        93    00:05:45.250 --> 00:05:48.750    OUR FACULTY TO IMPROVE THE    WORLD.        94    00:05:48.750 --> 00:05:52.520    ALISON SIMMONS AND BARBARA GROSS    WERE MAKING SURE THAT THE NEXT        95    00:05:52.520 --> 00:05:55.700    GENERATION OF COMPUTER    SCIENTISTS IS PREPARED TO        96    00:05:55.700 --> 00:05:59.640    ADDRESS THE ETHICAL QUESTIONS    POSED BY THE DEVELOPMENT OF NEW        97    00:05:59.640 --> 00:06:03.440    DIGITAL TECHNOLOGIES.        98    00:06:03.440 --> 00:06:06.750    -- HIS HOUSE ZERO, WHICH IS    DEMONSTRATING THE POSSIBILITIES        99    00:06:06.750 --> 00:06:11.100    OF ULTRAEFFICIENT DESIGN IN NEW    BUILDING TECHNOLOGY TO RESPOND        100    00:06:11.100 --> 00:06:17.900    TO THE THREAT OF CLIMATE    CHANGE -- REVEALING HOW MARRIAGE        101    00:06:17.900 --> 00:06:22.270    AND PARENTHOOD AFFECTS WAGES IN    HELPING US UNDERSTAND WHY        102    00:06:22.270 --> 00:06:27.210    ECONOMIC INEQUALITY PERSISTS    ACROSS GENERATIONS AND ALSO HOW        103    00:06:27.210 --> 00:06:30.800    WE MIGHT BREAK THE CYCLE OF    POVERTY.        104    00:06:30.800 --> 00:06:34.330    I'VE ALSO COME TO KNOW ABOUT THE    WORK OF CONNOR WALSH WHO'S        105    00:06:34.330 --> 00:06:37.000    HELPING PEOPLE WITH    NEURODEGENERATIVE AND        106    00:06:37.000 --> 00:06:42.650    NEUROMUSCULAR DISEASES WALK    AGAIN WITH SOFT EXOSUITS THAT        107    00:06:42.650 --> 00:06:45.880    USE THE LATEST ROBOTIC    TECHNOLOGY TO HELP IMPROVE        108    00:06:45.880 --> 00:06:46.880    MOVEMENT.        109    00:06:46.880 --> 00:06:51.680    OF SARAH WHO'S HELPING TO    ADDRESS THE OBESITY EPIDEMIC, BY        110    00:06:51.680 --> 00:06:54.400    CONSIDERING HOW CHANGES IN    PUBLIC POLICY CAN REDUCE        111    00:06:54.400 --> 00:06:59.220    CONSUMPTION OF HIGH CALORIE    FOODS AND SOFT DRINKS.        112    00:06:59.220 --> 00:07:03.780    OF TONY JACK, WHO'S CHANGING HOW    COLLEGES THINK ABOUT SUPPORTING        113    00:07:03.780 --> 00:07:07.780    DISADVANTAGED STUDENTS IN    IMPROVING THEIR PROSPECTS, NOT        114    00:07:07.780 --> 00:07:11.440    JUST IN COLLEGE, BUT THROUGHOUT    LIFE.        115    00:07:11.440 --> 00:07:14.810    OF ARLENE SHARP AND GORDON    FREEMAN WHO ARE GIVING HOPE TO        116    00:07:14.810 --> 00:07:19.120    CANCER PATIENTS BY HARNESSING    THE BODY'S OWN IMMUNE SYSTEM TO        117    00:07:19.120 --> 00:07:22.940    TREAT DISEASE.        118    00:07:22.940 --> 00:07:26.650    -- WHOSE SUPERRESOLUTION IMAGING    IS ENABLING SCIENTISTS TO LOOK        119    00:07:26.650 --> 00:07:32.030    INSIDE CELLS WITH UNPRECEDENTED    CLARITY AND SEE HOW MOLECULES        120    00:07:32.030 --> 00:07:34.960    FUNCTION AND INTERACT.        121    00:07:34.960 --> 00:07:40.090    OF ANDREW WHO HAS CULLED MASSIVE    AMOUNTS OF DATA FROM OUR TRIAL        122    00:07:40.090 --> 00:07:43.270    COURTS TO CHANGE HOW WE THINK    ABOUT OUR SYSTEM OF CRIMINAL        123    00:07:43.270 --> 00:07:47.330    JUSTICE AND HOW WE MIGHT    ACTUALLY IMPROVE IT.        124    00:07:47.330 --> 00:07:51.150    I'VE MET FACULTY ACROSS OUR    SCHOOLS WHO ARE EXPANDING        125    00:07:51.150 --> 00:07:54.340    RELIGIOUS LITERACY, WHO ARE    EXPLORING THE ROLE OF THE ARTS        126    00:07:54.340 --> 00:07:58.620    IN PROMOTING JUSTICE, WHO ARE    CONFRONTING THE OPIOID EPIDEMIC        127    00:07:58.620 --> 00:08:02.620    FROM EVERY ANGLE, WHO ARE    WORKING TO MAKE STATE AND LOCAL        128    00:08:02.620 --> 00:08:04.900    GOVERNMENT MORE EFFECTIVE.        129    00:08:04.900 --> 00:08:10.360    THEIR WORK IS NOTHING SHORT OF    INSPIRING AND I'VE COME TO KNOW        130    00:08:10.360 --> 00:08:11.900    OUR STUDENTS.        131    00:08:11.900 --> 00:08:17.870    ABSOLUTELY AMAZING STUDENTS, TO    THE PARENTS WHO ARE HERE, THANK        132    00:08:17.870 --> 00:08:23.830    YOU, THANK YOU FOR SENDING THESE    REMARKABLE YOUNG PEOPLE TO US.        133    00:08:23.830 --> 00:08:29.880    THEY ARE NOTHING SHORT OF    INSPIRING.        134    00:08:29.880 --> 00:08:35.990    [APPLAUSE]    INTERACTING WITH THEM IS ONE OF        135    00:08:35.990 --> 00:08:40.510    THE GREAT PRIVILEGES OF LIVING    AND WORKING ON A COLLEGE CAMPUS.        136    00:08:40.510 --> 00:08:43.860    ADELE AND I HAVE HAD DINNER WITH    THEM IN THE HOUSES.        137    00:08:43.860 --> 00:08:46.580    WE'VE WATCHED THEM PERFORM ON    THE STAGE AND ON THE PLAYING        138    00:08:46.580 --> 00:08:48.370    FIELDS.        139    00:08:48.370 --> 00:08:51.820    I'VE MET WITH THEM DURING OFFICE    HOURS AND TALKED TO THEM AS I'VE        140    00:08:51.820 --> 00:08:53.510    GONE RUNNING WITH THEM.        141    00:08:53.510 --> 00:08:58.640    IF YOU SPEND TIME WITH OUR    STUDENTS, YOU CANNOT HELP BUT        142    00:08:58.640 --> 00:09:02.330    FEEL OPTIMISTIC ABOUT OUR    FUTURE.        143    00:09:02.330 --> 00:09:06.230    THIS PAST WEEK I HAD LUNCH WITH    30 GRADUATING SENIORS.        144    00:09:06.230 --> 00:09:09.810    IT WAS WONDERFUL TO HEAR HOW    THEY THINK THEY HAVE CHANGED AND        145    00:09:09.810 --> 00:09:12.080    MATURED DURING THEIR FOUR YEARS    HERE.        146    00:09:12.080 --> 00:09:17.300    I ACTUALLY ASKED THEM HOW IS    YOUR CURRENT SELF DIFFERENT FROM        147    00:09:17.300 --> 00:09:22.320    YOUR 18-YEAR-OLD SELF THAT    ARRIVED HERE ON CAMPUS?        148    00:09:22.320 --> 00:09:24.170    AND THE STORIES WERE MARVELOUS.        149    00:09:24.170 --> 00:09:28.020    AND I'VE WITNESSED THIS PROCESS    OF TRANSFORMATION MYSELF.        150    00:09:28.020 --> 00:09:31.270    I HELPED TO ADVISE THREE OF OUR    INCOMING FIRST YEAR        151    00:09:31.270 --> 00:09:34.700    UNDERGRADUATES THIS YEAR AND    THEY HELPED ME EXPERIENCE AND        152    00:09:34.700 --> 00:09:40.260    UNDERSTAND HARVARD THROUGH THEIR    EYES, TO ANDREW, CLAIRE AND        153    00:09:40.260 --> 00:09:43.880    KAREN, THANK YOU FOR SHARING    YOUR FIRST YEAR FOR ME AND FOR        154    00:09:43.880 --> 00:09:46.520    TEACHING ME SO WELL.        155    00:09:46.520 --> 00:09:51.571    FOR EVERY PERSON I'VE NAMED, FOR    EVERY EXAMPLE I'VE CITED, THERE        156    00:09:51.571 --> 00:09:56.220    ARE THOUSANDS OF OTHER HARVARD    CITIZENS, STUDENTS AND ALUMNI,        157    00:09:56.220 --> 00:09:59.920    FACULTY AND STAFF, WHO ARE    MAKING THE WORLD BETTER IN MORE        158    00:09:59.920 --> 00:10:03.700    WAYS THAN WE COULD POSSIBLY    IMAGINE.        159    00:10:03.700 --> 00:10:09.610    THAT IS THE POWER OF THIS    INSTITUTION, NOT ITS BRAND, NOT        160    00:10:09.610 --> 00:10:14.120    OUR BUILDINGS, NOT OUR POMP AND    CIRCUMSTANCE, AS WONDERFUL AND        161    00:10:14.120 --> 00:10:20.160    TERRIFIC AS THAT IS, THIS    UNIVERSITY, HARVARD IS ITS        162    00:10:20.160 --> 00:10:25.200    PEOPLE, THEIR ASPIRATIONS, THEIR    ACHIEVEMENTS, THEIR DIVERSITY OF        163    00:10:25.200 --> 00:10:29.670    BACKGROUND, EXPERIENCE, AND    THOUGHT, THEIR DESIRE TO SEE        164    00:10:29.670 --> 00:10:34.750    BEYOND THEMSELVES AND THEIR    DEVOTION TO SERVING OTHERS.        165    00:10:34.750 --> 00:10:37.570    SO YES, I AM AN OPTIMIST.        166    00:10:37.570 --> 00:10:41.950    I'M AN OPTIMIST BECAUSE I LIVE    AND WORK AMONG ALL OF YOU        167    00:10:41.950 --> 00:10:45.150    BECAUSE I SEE WHAT YOU CAN DO    AND BECAUSE I KNOW THE BOUNDLESS        168    00:10:45.150 --> 00:10:48.470    POTENTIAL OF WHAT YOU CAN DO.        169    00:10:48.470 --> 00:10:52.430    MAY WE LOOK AT ONE ANOTHER FOR    INSPIRATION IN THE YEARS TO        170    00:10:52.430 --> 00:10:57.950    COME, MAY THE EXPECTATIONS    PLACED ON US BE COMPETED ONLY BY        171    00:10:57.950 --> 00:11:02.030    OUR ABILITY TO MEET THEM AND MAY    HARVARD CONTINUE TO BE A        172    00:11:02.030 --> 00:11:05.750    WELLSPRING OF HOPE FOR THE    WORLD.        173    00:11:05.750 --> 00:11:09.210    IT'S AN HONOR TO SERVE YOU AS    YOU PRESIDENT.        174    00:11:09.210 --> 00:11:13.450    CONGRATULATIONS TO OUR NEWEST    ALUMNI AND THANK YOU TO ALL.

title: Senior English address by Genesis De Los Santos | Harvard Commencement 2019
desc: Senior English speaker Genesis De Los Santos addresses fellow students in the Class of 2019 at Harvard's Commencement ceremonies on May 30, 2019.
speech_raw: 1    00:00:01.560 --> 00:00:03.860    >> IF YOU TAKE THE RED LINE TO        2    00:00:03.860 --> 00:00:06.060    PARK STREET,        3    00:00:06.400 --> 00:00:12.219    SWITCH ONTO THE    ORANGE LINE TOWARDS FOREST HILLS        4    00:00:12.219 --> 00:00:18.369    PAST THE HUSTLING VENDORS AND    THE SMELLS OF FRESH ROASTED        5    00:00:18.369 --> 00:00:21.060    PEANUTS TOASTING,        6    00:00:21.060 --> 00:00:24.720    AND GET OFF AT    THE VERY LAST STOP,        7    00:00:25.740 --> 00:00:26.360    YOU'LL END        8    00:00:26.420 --> 00:00:26.920    UP THERE.        9    00:00:29.380 --> 00:00:38.400    NO, NOT HARVARD'S ARNOLD    ARBORETUM, BUT INSTEAD THE SOUTH        10    00:00:38.410 --> 00:00:42.540    STREET HOUSING DEVELOPMENT.        11    00:00:42.540 --> 00:00:47.060    LIKE HARVARD, IT IS A PLACE    FILLED WITH DREAMERS, FUTURE        12    00:00:47.060 --> 00:00:51.580    CHANGEMAKERS, AND ASPIRING    ARTISTS;        13    00:00:52.360 --> 00:00:55.400    THE ONLY DIFFERENCE:        14    00:00:55.400 --> 00:00:58.800    OPPORTUNITY.        15    00:00:58.800 --> 00:01:09.289    AT THE COLLEGE -- WELD HALL,    ELIOT HOUSE -- [CHEERING]        16    00:01:09.289 --> 00:01:11.940    THEY AREN'T TOO    DIFFERENT FROM THE APARTMENT        17    00:01:11.940 --> 00:01:15.320    BUILDINGS I GREW UP IN.        18    00:01:15.320 --> 00:01:18.720    PAINT PEELS OFF OF THE WALLS,        19    00:01:18.720 --> 00:01:20.720    [LAUGHING]        20    00:01:21.580 --> 00:01:24.360    PET COCKROACHES OCCASIONALLY        21    00:01:24.360 --> 00:01:26.520    APPEAR IN THE SHOWERS.        22    00:01:28.320 --> 00:01:33.560    BUT, MORE IMPORTANTLY, LOVING    COMMUNITY MEMBERS ENVELOP YOU        23    00:01:33.569 --> 00:01:36.229    WITH THEIR KINDNESS.        24    00:01:36.229 --> 00:01:43.240    THOSE BRICK BUILDINGS, THOUGH    THEY'RE RIGID AND COLD ON THE OUTSIDE,        25    00:01:43.240 --> 00:01:48.400    ARE HOME TO A ROARING HEARTH.        26    00:01:48.400 --> 00:01:54.259    THE PEOPLE, LIKE MY FORMER    NEIGHBOR, VECINA ANA, WHOSE        27    00:01:54.259 --> 00:02:01.109    SMILE REVEALS A GLIMPSE OF THE    METAL CAP ON HER TOOTH, ARE        28    00:02:01.109 --> 00:02:02.109    FAMILY.        29    00:02:02.109 --> 00:02:09.540    THE FIRST RESPONDERS WHEN YOU    ARE IN NEED.        30    00:02:09.540 --> 00:02:15.930    ON AUGUST 3, 2006, I WAS EIGHT    YEARS OLD WHEN MY MOTHER        31    00:02:15.930 --> 00:02:21.480    RECEIVED A CALL THAT WOULD    CHANGE EVERYTHING.        32    00:02:21.480 --> 00:02:25.629    MY FATHER HAD SUFFERED A CAR    ACCIDENT IN THE DOMINICAN        33    00:02:25.629 --> 00:02:31.409    REPUBLIC WHILE ON HIS WAY TO    VISIT MY GRANDMOTHER.        34    00:02:31.409 --> 00:02:35.390    IT WAS OUT BACK BY THE GREEN    DUMPSTERS THAT MY MAMI        35    00:02:35.390 --> 00:02:40.170    RELINQUISHED EVERY SENSE OF    BEING, FALLING ONTO THE COLD        36    00:02:40.170 --> 00:02:43.670    CONCRETE IN DISBELIEF.        37    00:02:43.670 --> 00:02:52.230    AN IMMIGRANT, ALONE WITH NOW    IMMEDIATE FAMILY HERE,        38    00:02:52.230 --> 00:02:59.770    MY MOTHER DEPENDED ON THE SOUTH    STREET HOUSING DEVELOPMENT.        39    00:02:59.770 --> 00:03:04.530    FOR AN ENTIRE YEAR, DURING THE    MANY MONTHS OF MY FATHER'S        40    00:03:04.530 --> 00:03:11.319    MULTIPLE COMAE AND SURGERIES,    THIS COMMUNITY FED US, CLOTHED        41    00:03:11.319 --> 00:03:15.430    US, AND WATCHED US.        42    00:03:15.430 --> 00:03:20.069    IT WAS ON THE PLAYGROUNDS OF    THIS CONCRETE JUNGLE THAT I        43    00:03:20.069 --> 00:03:24.969    LEARNED WHAT A HOME LOOKED LIKE.        44    00:03:24.969 --> 00:03:30.829    EVERY VECINA IN OUR BUILDING, AT    4 METCALF COURT, LIT A CANDLE        45    00:03:30.829 --> 00:03:33.920    FOR MY FAMILY.        46    00:03:33.920 --> 00:03:39.709    IT WAS THE FLICKER OF THOSE RED    CANDLES THAT BROUGHT MY FAMILY        47    00:03:39.709 --> 00:03:48.390    AND ME ALL OF THE WAY HERE TO    HARVARD YARD.        48    00:03:48.390 --> 00:03:58.100    [CHEERS & APPLAUSE]    I REMEMBER SITTING IN THE        49    00:03:58.100 --> 00:04:02.001    STAIRWELLS OF WELD HALL ON    MOVE-IN DAY, LOOKING UP AT MY        50    00:04:02.001 --> 00:04:04.609    FATHER.        51    00:04:04.609 --> 00:04:08.959    THAT DAY WAS THE FIRST TIME IN    30 YEARS OF LIVING IN THE UNITED        52    00:04:08.959 --> 00:04:11.969    STATES, OF LIVING IN THE STATE    OF MASSACHUSETTS, IN BOSTON,        53    00:04:11.969 --> 00:04:16.670    THAT HE HAD    STEPPED FOOT INTO HARVARD YARD.        54    00:04:16.670 --> 00:04:22.620    AS I SAT THERE, I RECALLED THE    DAY THAT I, A 12-YEAR-OLD GIRL,        55    00:04:22.620 --> 00:04:30.889    WAS MOVING OUT OF HER HOME AT    METCALF COURT.        56    00:04:30.889 --> 00:04:36.080    WHEN WE LEFT THOSE PROJECT    BUILDINGS, MY PARENTS DID NOT        57    00:04:36.080 --> 00:04:38.460    LOOK BACK.        58    00:04:38.460 --> 00:04:42.360    BUT TODAY, I DO.        59    00:04:42.360 --> 00:04:46.610    IN THAT MOMENT, SITTING ON THOSE    STAIRS IN WELD, I REMEMBERED HOW        60    00:04:46.610 --> 00:04:51.000    I, AS A CHILD, WOULD SIT AND    WAIT FOR MY SCHOOL BUS ON THE        61    00:04:51.000 --> 00:04:54.389    STAIRWELLS IN MY APARTMENT    BUILDING.        62    00:04:54.389 --> 00:05:07.070    I THOUGHT TO MYSELF AND REALIZED    JUST HOW FAR I HAD TRAVELED.        63    00:05:07.070 --> 00:05:13.610    THOUGH FAIRLY CLOSE, CAMBRIDGE--    LET ME BE MORE SPECIFIC--        64    00:05:13.610 --> 00:05:19.199    HARVARD STILL FEELS WORLDS APART    FROM THE COURTYARDS AT SOUTH        65    00:05:19.199 --> 00:05:23.500    STREET THAT GAVE ME MY FIRST    SCARS WHEN I FELL OFF OF        66    00:05:23.500 --> 00:05:30.160    YAMILEX'S MAGENTA    BARBIE-STICKERED BIKE.        67    00:05:30.160 --> 00:05:34.880    THESE BRICK BUILDINGS, THOUGH    THEIR FACADE MAY BE SIMILAR,        68    00:05:34.880 --> 00:05:42.389    STILL SWELL WITH THE PRIVILEGE    THAT LIES BEHIND THEIR WALLS,        69    00:05:42.389 --> 00:05:49.199    THE PRIVILEGE OF OPPORTUNITY.        70    00:05:49.199 --> 00:05:54.289    HERE AT HARVARD, I HAVE FOUND    WOMEN SIMILAR TO ANA-- A LOT        71    00:05:54.289 --> 00:06:01.060    YOUNGER, BUT ALSO WILLING TO    STAY UP WITH ME AS I FILLED        72    00:06:01.060 --> 00:06:06.050    ELIOT'S D ENTRYWAY WITH SHRILL    CRIES WHEN MY MOTHER WAS        73    00:06:06.050 --> 00:06:10.620    DIAGNOSED WITH CANCER.        74    00:06:10.620 --> 00:06:17.280    IF THE WALLS IN ELIOT HOUSE, IF    THE WALLS AT 4 METCALF COURT,        75    00:06:17.280 --> 00:06:21.190    COULD SPEAK, THEY WOULD HAVE    ENOUGH STORIES TO FILL SEVERAL        76    00:06:21.190 --> 00:06:30.720    NOVELS, TESTIFYING TO THE PAIN    AND TRAUMA, BUT MORE IMPORTANTLY        77    00:06:30.720 --> 00:06:34.020    THE    LOVE AND SUPPORT I'VE RECEIVED        78    00:06:34.020 --> 00:06:39.690    IN MY VARIOUS HOMES.        79    00:06:39.690 --> 00:06:45.669    HARVARD IS A HOME, AND WE ALL    HAVE COMPLICATED RELATIONSHIPS        80    00:06:45.669 --> 00:06:49.970    WITH HOME.        81    00:06:49.970 --> 00:06:55.470    BUT IT IS A PLACE THAT HAS    TOUCHED US ALL.        82    00:06:55.470 --> 00:06:59.360    AND AS WE LEAVE THIS HOME THAT    WE HAVE CREATED HERE AS A        83    00:06:59.360 --> 00:07:05.940    COMMUNITY, I URGE US TO THINK    ABOUT THE OPPORTUNITIES THAT WE        84    00:07:05.940 --> 00:07:09.370    HAVE BEEN GIVEN.        85    00:07:09.370 --> 00:07:14.319    LET US THINK ABOUT THE    PRIVILEGES GRANTED TO US AS WE        86    00:07:14.319 --> 00:07:21.220    GO THROUGH THE WORLD CARRYING A    HARVARD DIPLOMA.        87    00:07:21.220 --> 00:07:28.819    LET US REFLECT, BUT MORE    IMPORTANTLY, BE        88    00:07:28.819 --> 00:07:30.280    CONSCIOUS.        89    00:07:30.280 --> 00:07:39.190    CONSCIOUS OF THE WEIGHT THAT OUR    EDUCATION HOLDS.        90    00:07:39.190 --> 00:07:44.111    CONSCIOUS OF ALL OF THOSE WHO    SIMPLY DO NOT HAVE THE        91    00:07:44.111 --> 00:07:47.669    OPPORTUNITY.        92    00:07:47.669 --> 00:07:54.389    IT COULD RIGHTFULLY HAVE BEEN    SOMEONE ELSE IN OUR PLACE, BUT        93    00:07:54.389 --> 00:07:56.889    IT WAS US.        94    00:07:56.889 --> 00:08:05.320    NOW, WHAT WILL WE DO WITH WHAT    WE HAVE GAINED HERE?        95    00:08:05.320 --> 00:08:12.169    I HOPE THAT AS WE ANSWER THIS    FOR OURSELVES, WE LEAD NOT WITH        96    00:08:12.169 --> 00:08:19.159    OUR PRIVILEGE BUT INSTEAD WORK    WITH A DESIRE TO CREATE        97    00:08:19.159 --> 00:08:33.930    OPPORTUNITIES FOR OTHERS.        98    00:08:33.930 --> 00:08:40.640    [APPLAUSE]

title: Author Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie addresses Harvard's Class of 2018
desc: Award-winning author Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie addresses Harvard's Class of 2018 on Class Day, May 23, 2018.         A Nigerian-born writer whose work has been translated into more than 30 languages, Adichie is the author of the novels â€œPurple Hibiscus,â€ which won the Commonwealth Writersâ€™ Prize and the Hurston/Wright Legacy Award; â€œHalf of a Yellow Sun,â€ which won the Orange Prize; and â€œAmericanah,â€ a 2013 National Book Critics Circle Award winner, which she finalized during a fellowship year at the Radcliffe Institute for Advanced Study. Her most recent book, â€œDear Ijeawele, or A Feminist Manifesto in Fifteen Suggestions,â€ was published in March 2017.

good fortune enough to give    its fruits away but if it's any        103    00:09:34.610 --> 00:09:38.930    consolation there's a reason that the    inscription facing you as you leave the        104    00:09:38.930 --> 00:09:47.180    yard says depart to serve better thy    country and mankind not depart to serve        105    00:09:47.180 --> 00:09:55.880    better thyself and I can thus I believe    truly taking this adage seriously and        106    00:09:55.880 --> 00:10:01.490    taking it to heart requires us to ask    ourselves a slightly different form of        107    00:10:01.490 --> 00:10:05.950    the question we all know the answer to        108    00:10:06.940 --> 00:10:15.730    what am I going to do for others with my    talents thank you        109    00:10:18.670 --> 00:10:20.730    you

title: Congressman John Lewis Address | Harvard Commencement 2018
desc: Congressman and Civil Rights leader John Lewis gave his address at Harvard's 367th Commencement on May 24, 2018 at Tercentenary Theatre. For more information, visit https://news.harvard.edu/gazette/story/series/commencement-2018/.
speech_raw: 1    00:00:02.010 --> 00:00:04.060    >> THANK YOU SO MUCH.        2    00:00:04.060 --> 00:00:07.670    FOR THOSE KIND WORDS OF    INTRODUCTION.        3    00:00:07.670 --> 00:00:12.620    I MUST TELL YOU THAT I'M    DELIGHTED, VERY PLEASED AND        4    00:00:12.620 --> 00:00:17.070    REALLY HAPPY TO BE HEAR YOU LOOK    GOOD!        5    00:00:17.070 --> 00:00:21.860    [LAUGHTER]    THE WEATHER IS GOOD, RAIN STAYED        6    00:00:21.860 --> 00:00:22.940    AWAY.        7    00:00:22.940 --> 00:00:25.100    I'M HAPPY.        8    00:00:25.100 --> 00:00:34.559    IT'S GOOD TO SEE EACH AND EVERY    ONE OF YOU.        9    00:00:34.559 --> 00:00:38.300    FELLOWS OF HARVARD UNIVERSITY,    MEMBERS OF        10    00:00:38.300 --> 00:00:43.179    THE BOARD OF OVERSEERS, MEMBERS    OF THE ALUMNI BOARD,        11    00:00:43.179 --> 00:00:52.179    DISTINGUISHED DEANS, GUESTS,    FACULTY AND ALL OF THE STUDENTS,        12    00:00:52.179 --> 00:01:04.769    ALL OF THE WONDERFUL GRADUATES,    AND MADAM PRESIDENT, THANK YOU.        13    00:01:04.769 --> 00:01:10.680    THANK YOU FOR YOUR LEADERSHIP,    THANK YOU FOR GETTING IN GOOD        14    00:01:10.680 --> 00:01:11.680    TROUBLE!        15    00:01:11.680 --> 00:01:13.530    [LAUGHTER]    NECESSARY TROUBLE.        16    00:01:13.530 --> 00:01:16.970    TO LEAD THIS GREAT UNIVERSITY.        17    00:01:16.970 --> 00:01:20.010    I WANT TO TAKE JUST A MOMENT TO    HONOR        18    00:01:20.010 --> 00:01:24.770    THE TENURE OF A GREAT LEADER,    WHO, THROUGH HER COURAGE AND        19    00:01:24.770 --> 00:01:29.430    VISION, WORKED TO LEAD THIS    HISTORIC UNIVERSITY TO EVEN        20    00:01:29.430 --> 00:01:32.350    HIGHER HEIGHTS.        21    00:01:32.350 --> 00:01:37.160    MADAM PRESIDENT, THANK YOU FOR    BEING A FRIEND, BUT MORE        22    00:01:37.160 --> 00:01:41.990    IMPORTANTLY, THANK YOU FOR USING    YOUR OFFICE TO MOVE HARVARD        23    00:01:41.990 --> 00:01:51.130    TOWARD A MORE ALL-INCLUSIVE    INSTITUTION.        24    00:01:51.130 --> 00:01:58.430    [APPLAUSE]    SOMEWHERE ALONG THE WAY, YOU        25    00:01:58.430 --> 00:02:03.720    REALIZED THAT THE BRILLIANT MIND    IS NOT CONFINED TO ONE        26    00:02:03.720 --> 00:02:08.200    DISCIPLINE OR ONE WAY OF    THINKING.        27    00:02:08.200 --> 00:02:13.780    IN FACT, TRUE GENIUS SEES    CONNECTIONS AND RELATIONSHIPS        28    00:02:13.780 --> 00:02:17.930    ACROSS BARRIERS, TO BUILD A NEW    UNDERSTANDING OF THE WORLD        29    00:02:17.930 --> 00:02:20.189    AROUND US.        30    00:02:20.189 --> 00:02:24.800    CREATING ONE HARVARD IS MUCH    LIKE THE WORK I DEDICATED MY        31    00:02:24.800 --> 00:02:26.400    LIFE TO.        32    00:02:26.400 --> 00:02:34.219    EVER SINCE AS A YOUNG GIRL YOU    WROTE A LETTER        33    00:02:34.219 --> 00:02:37.609    TO PRESIDENT EISENHOWER AS A    LITTLE GIRL, YOU HAVE BEEN        34    00:02:37.609 --> 00:02:43.260    RESPONDING TO THE CRY FOR HUMAN    DIGNITY THAT RINGS OUT IN OUR        35    00:02:43.260 --> 00:02:44.260    WORLD.        36    00:02:44.260 --> 00:02:47.769    YOU USED YOUR VISION AND YOUR    TALENT, YOU USED THE GREAT        37    00:02:47.769 --> 00:02:53.959    RESOURCES OF THIS UNIVERSITY TO    RESPOND TO THAT CALL, AND I        38    00:02:53.959 --> 00:02:56.010    THANK YOU.        39    00:02:56.010 --> 00:03:01.840    THANK YOU FOR YOUR CONTRIBUTION    TO HUMAN UNITY IN OUR WORLD        40    00:03:01.840 --> 00:03:04.030    TODAY.        41    00:03:04.030 --> 00:03:07.989    I SAY    TO EACH AND EVERY ONE OF YOU WHO        42    00:03:07.989 --> 00:03:18.010    GRADUATED FROM THIS UNIVERSITY,    YOU MUST LEAD.        43    00:03:18.010 --> 00:03:22.439    YOU'RE NEVER TOO YOUNG TO LEAD,    YOU'RE NEVER TOO OLD TO LEAD!        44    00:03:22.439 --> 00:03:27.459    WE NEED YOUR LEADERSHIP NOW MORE    THAN EVERY BEFORE.        45    00:03:27.459 --> 00:03:31.959    WE NEED IT!        46    00:03:31.959 --> 00:03:42.790    [APPLAUSE]    WE MUST SAVE OUR COUNTRY!        47    00:03:42.790 --> 00:03:45.849    WE MUST SAVE IT!        48    00:03:45.849 --> 00:03:54.719    [APPLAUSE]    WE MUST SAVE OUR DEMOCRACY.        49    00:03:54.719 --> 00:04:00.819    [APPLAUSE]    THERE ARE FORCES IN AMERICA        50    00:04:00.819 --> 00:04:05.329    TODAY AND AROUND THE WORLD    TRYING TO TAKE US TO SOME OTHER        51    00:04:05.329 --> 00:04:08.309    PLACE.        52    00:04:08.309 --> 00:04:15.290    OUR FOREMOTHERS AND FOREFATHERS    BROUGHT US TO THIS PLACE.        53    00:04:15.290 --> 00:04:19.190    MAYBE OUR FOREMOTHERS AND OUR    FOREFATHER'S ALL CAME TO THIS        54    00:04:19.190 --> 00:04:24.480    GREAT WORLD IN DIFFERENT SHIPS    BUT AS THE LATE GREAT RANDOLPH        55    00:04:24.480 --> 00:04:30.760    SAID "WE ARE ALL IN THE SAME    BOAT NOW" AND WE MUST LOOK OUT        56    00:04:30.760 --> 00:04:35.720    FOR EACH OTHER AND CARE FOR EACH    OTHER.        57    00:04:35.720 --> 00:04:43.860    [APPLAUSE]    YOU'RE NEVER TOO YOUNG OR TOO        58    00:04:43.860 --> 00:04:45.230    OLD TO LEAD!        59    00:04:45.230 --> 00:04:46.590    TO SPEAK UP!        60    00:04:46.590 --> 00:04:47.630    SPEAK OUT!        61    00:04:47.630 --> 00:04:55.440    AND GET IN GOOD TROUBLE,    NECESSARY TROUBLE.        62    00:04:55.440 --> 00:05:00.670    YOU CANNOT AFFORD TO STAND ON    THE SIDELINES.        63    00:05:00.670 --> 00:05:04.540    ANOTHER GENERATION OF YOUNG    PEOPLE AND PEOPLE NOT SO YOUNG        64    00:05:04.540 --> 00:05:10.270    ARE INSPIRED TO GET IN THE WAY.        65    00:05:10.270 --> 00:05:14.970    STUDENTS FROM HARVARD, DR.        66    00:05:14.970 --> 00:05:20.910    COLE,    WHO I HAVE BEEN KNOWING FOR MANY        67    00:05:20.910 --> 00:05:29.720    YEARS CAME TO MISSISSIPPI, CAME    TO THE SOUTH AND GAVE EVERYTHING        68    00:05:29.720 --> 00:05:32.940    YOU HAD.        69    00:05:32.940 --> 00:05:41.430    DURING THE 63 YOUNG MEN THAT I    KNEW, ANA GOODMAN, NICK WILL YOU        70    00:05:41.430 --> 00:05:46.960    SAY SHRENER AND JAMES GAVE THEIR    LIVES WHILE THEY WERE HELPING        71    00:05:46.960 --> 00:05:51.860    PEOPLE TO REGISTER TO VOTE.        72    00:05:51.860 --> 00:05:53.240    THE VOTE IS PRECIOUS.        73    00:05:53.240 --> 00:05:55.770    IT'S ALMOST SACRED.        74    00:05:55.770 --> 00:06:00.210    IT IS THE MOST POWERFUL,    NONINSTRUMENT OR TOOL WE HAVE IN        75    00:06:00.210 --> 00:06:04.390    A DEMOCRATIC SOCIETY AND WE MUST    USE T IF WE FAIL TO USE IT, WE        76    00:06:04.390 --> 00:06:10.190    WILL LOSE IT.        77    00:06:10.190 --> 00:06:18.600    [APPLAUSE]    SO DURING THIS ELECTION YEAR, I        78    00:06:18.600 --> 00:06:28.530    URGE YOU, I PLEAD WITH YOU TO DO    WHAT YOU CAN TO SAVE AND RESCUE        79    00:06:28.530 --> 00:06:29.840    AMERICA.        80    00:06:29.840 --> 00:06:33.350    TO DO WHAT YOU CAN TO SAVE THE    PLANET!        81    00:06:33.350 --> 00:06:41.160    SAVE THIS SPACESHIP WE CALL    EARTH AND LEAVE IT A LITTLE        82    00:06:41.160 --> 00:06:45.600    CLEANER, A LITTLE GREENER, AND A    LITTLE MORE PEACEFUL.        83    00:06:45.600 --> 00:06:52.620    FOR GENERATIONS YET UNBORN.        84    00:06:52.620 --> 00:06:59.420    [APPLAUSE]    WE HAVE A MISSION AND A MANDATE        85    00:06:59.420 --> 00:07:04.490    TO GO OUT THERE, PLAY A ROLE AND    PLAY IT SO WELL AS DR.        86    00:07:04.490 --> 00:07:06.530    KING    WOULD SAY, THAT NO ONE ELSE CAN        87    00:07:06.530 --> 00:07:10.280    PLAY IT ANY BETTER.        88    00:07:10.280 --> 00:07:18.170    SMV YOU HAVE HEARD ME SAY FROM    TIME TO TIME THAT I GREW UP IN        89    00:07:18.170 --> 00:07:22.230    RURAL ALABAMA ON A FARM.        90    00:07:22.230 --> 00:07:26.850    PICKING COTTON, GATHERING    PEANUTS, GATHERING CORN,        91    00:07:26.850 --> 00:07:29.370    SOMETIMES I WOULD BE OUT THERE    WORKING AND MY MOTHER WOULD SAY,        92    00:07:29.370 --> 00:07:30.370    "BOY, YOU'RE FALLING BEHIND!        93    00:07:30.370 --> 00:07:35.910    YOU NEED TO CATCH UP" AND I    WOULD SAY "THIS IS HARD WORK AND        94    00:07:35.910 --> 00:07:38.950    SHE SAID "HARD WORK NEVER KILLED    ANYBODY AND I SAID I SAY ABOUT        95    00:07:38.950 --> 00:07:41.430    TO KILL ME!        96    00:07:41.430 --> 00:07:44.950    [LAUGHTER]    WE NEED TO WORK HARD!        97    00:07:44.950 --> 00:07:49.710    THERE IS WORK TO BE DONE.        98    00:07:49.710 --> 00:07:56.110    THESE SMART GRADUATES WILL LEAD    US.        99    00:07:56.110 --> 00:08:04.050    HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS LEAD US,    AND GUYS, I SAY TO YOU, IF        100    00:08:04.050 --> 00:08:17.340    YOU'RE NOT MINDFUL, THE WOMEN    ARE GOING TO LEAD US!        101    00:08:17.340 --> 00:08:23.100    [CHEERS & APPLAUSE]    IT IS MY BELIEF, IT IS MY        102    00:08:23.100 --> 00:08:28.970    FEELING AS A TRAVELLER OF    AMERICA THAT THE WOMEN AND YOUNG        103    00:08:28.970 --> 00:08:33.029    PEOPLE, HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS,    ELEMENTARY SCHOOL STUDENTS AND        104    00:08:33.029 --> 00:08:41.840    COLLEGE STUDENTS WILL LEAD US AS    PART OF A NONVIOLENT REVOLUTION.        105    00:08:41.840 --> 00:08:50.310    WE WILL CREATE AN AMERICA THAT    IS BETTER, A LITTLE MORE HUMANE        106    00:08:50.310 --> 00:08:56.140    AND NO ONE, BUT NO ONE CAN DENY    US OF THAT.        107    00:08:56.140 --> 00:09:03.520    [APPLAUSE]    I JUST WANT TO SAY ONE OR TWO        108    00:09:03.520 --> 00:09:06.320    WORDS TO THE GRADUATES.        109    00:09:06.320 --> 00:09:11.080    TAKE A DEEP BREATH AND TAKE IT    ALL IN.        110    00:09:11.080 --> 00:09:17.860    BUT TOMORROW, I HOPE YOU ROLL UP    YOUR SLEEVES, BECAUSE THE WORLD        111    00:09:17.860 --> 00:09:21.940    IS WAITING FOR TALENTED MEN AND    WOMEN TO LEAD IT TO A BETTER        112    00:09:21.940 --> 00:09:23.360    PLACE.        113    00:09:23.360 --> 00:09:31.480    DURING THE 60s, PEOPLE LITERALLY    PUT THEIR BODIES ON THE LINE!        114    00:09:31.480 --> 00:09:38.170    MANY CAME FROM THIS UNIVERSITY,    CAME FROM CAMBRIDGE, FROM        115    00:09:38.170 --> 00:09:43.180    BOSTON, THROUGHOUT THE STATE AND    THROUGHOUT AMERICA.        116    00:09:43.180 --> 00:09:48.570    JUST THINK A FEW SHORT YEARS AGO    THAT BLACK PEOPLE AND WHITE        117    00:09:48.570 --> 00:09:52.860    PEOPLE COULDN'T BE SEATED    TOGETHER ON A GREYHOUND BUSINESS        118    00:09:52.860 --> 00:09:55.210    OR TRAILWAY BUS, LEAVING    WASHINGTON, D.C.        119    00:09:55.210 --> 00:09:58.570    TO TRAVEL    THROUGH VIRGINIA, NORTH        120    00:09:58.570 --> 00:10:01.850    CAROLINA, SOUTH CAROLINA,    GEORGIA, ALABAMA, MISSISSIPPI.        121    00:10:01.850 --> 00:10:06.380    WE WERE ON OUR WAY TO NEW    ORLEANS TO TEST A DECISION OF        122    00:10:06.380 --> 00:10:08.330    THE UNITED STATES SUPREME COURT.        123    00:10:08.330 --> 00:10:17.960    WE WERE BEATEN, ARRESTED, AND    MORE THAN 400 OF US WERE JAILED.        124    00:10:17.960 --> 00:10:25.520    MY SEAT MATE WAS A YOUNG WHITE    GENTLEMAN FROM CONNECTICUT.        125    00:10:25.520 --> 00:10:30.960    WE ARRIVED IN A SMALL TOWN IN    SOUTH CAROLINA.        126    00:10:30.960 --> 00:10:36.510    WE WERE BEATEN, LEFT BLOODY.        127    00:10:36.510 --> 00:10:41.380    BUT MANY YEARS LATER AND THIS    WAS MAY, 1961, SAME YEAR THAT        128    00:10:41.380 --> 00:10:48.110    BARACK OBAMA WAS BORN, BUT MANY    YEARS LATER, ONE OF THE GUYS        129    00:10:48.110 --> 00:10:53.290    THAT BEAT US CAME TO MY OFFICE    IN WASHINGTON.        130    00:10:53.290 --> 00:10:56.900    HE GOT INFORMATION FROM A LOCAL    REPORTER.        131    00:10:56.900 --> 00:11:02.200    HE WAS IN HIS 70s, HIS SON CAME    WITH HIM IN HIS 40s.        132    00:11:02.200 --> 00:11:04.040    HE SAID, MR.        133    00:11:04.040 --> 00:11:07.400    LEWIS, I'M ONE OF    THE PEOPLE THAT BEAT YOU.        134    00:11:07.400 --> 00:11:09.610    BEAT YOUR SEATMATE.        135    00:11:09.610 --> 00:11:12.290    I'VE BEEN A MEMBER OF THE KLAN.        136    00:11:12.290 --> 00:11:18.380    HE SAID "WILL YOU FOR GIVE ME?"        137    00:11:18.380 --> 00:11:21.110    "I WANT TO APOLOGIZE."        138    00:11:21.110 --> 00:11:24.310    "WILL YOU ACCEPT MY APOLOGY?        139    00:11:24.310 --> 00:11:28.200    WILL YOU FOR GIVE ME?"        140    00:11:28.200 --> 00:11:33.040    HIS SON STARTED CRYING, HE    STARTED CRYING AND I SAID I FOR        141    00:11:33.040 --> 00:11:34.040    GIVE YOU.        142    00:11:34.040 --> 00:11:36.500    I ACCEPT YOUR APOLOGY.        143    00:11:36.500 --> 00:11:41.880    THEY HUGGED ME, I HUGGED THEM    BACK AND I CRIED WITH THEM.        144    00:11:41.880 --> 00:11:47.770    IN POWER OF THE WAY OF PEACE,    THE POWER OF LOVE, IT IS THE        145    00:11:47.770 --> 00:11:53.120    POWER OF THE PHILOSOPHY AND    DISCIPLINE OF NONVIOLENCE.        146    00:11:53.120 --> 00:11:57.250    WE NEED TO CREATE A SOCIETY    WHERE WE CAN BE RECONCILED AND        147    00:11:57.250 --> 00:12:03.540    LAY DOWN THE BURDEN OF HATH FOR    HATE IS TOO HEAVY OF A BURDEN TO        148    00:12:03.540 --> 00:12:06.080    BEAR.        149    00:12:06.080 --> 00:12:17.920    [APPLAUSE]    50 YEARS AGO THE MAN THAT I        150    00:12:17.920 --> 00:12:26.540    ADMIRED, THE MAN THAT WAS LIKE A    BROTHER, MARTIN LUTHER KING,        151    00:12:26.540 --> 00:12:29.510    JUNIOR, WAS TAKEN FROM US.        152    00:12:29.510 --> 00:12:32.100    WHEN WE HEARD THAT DR.        153    00:12:32.100 --> 00:12:35.210    KING HAD    BEEN ASSASSINATED I WAS IN        154    00:12:35.210 --> 00:12:43.850    INDIANAPOLIS, INDIANA    CAMPAIGNING WITH BOBBY KENNEDY.        155    00:12:43.850 --> 00:12:48.930    I CRIED.        156    00:12:48.930 --> 00:12:59.490    STOPPED CRYING AND I SAID TO    MYSELF "WE STILL HAVE BOBBY."        157    00:12:59.490 --> 00:13:03.430    TWO MONTHS LATER BOBBY KEPT DID    I WAS GONE -- KENNEDY WAS GONE        158    00:13:03.430 --> 00:13:07.000    AND I CRIED SOME MORE.        159    00:13:07.000 --> 00:13:15.670    TODAY WE'VE GOT TO GET RID OF    OUR ARE TEARS AND NOT BE DOWN        160    00:13:15.670 --> 00:13:18.290    AND NOT GET LOST IN THE SEA OF    DESPAIR.        161    00:13:18.290 --> 00:13:24.520    WE'VE GOT TO BE HOPEFUL AND KEEP    THE FAITH AND TURN THE SHIP        162    00:13:24.520 --> 00:13:25.520    AROUND.        163    00:13:25.520 --> 00:13:31.970    WE CAN DO IT AND WE MUST DO IT!        164    00:13:31.970 --> 00:13:40.649    [APPLAUSE]    HERE AT HARVARD YOU'VE BEEN WELL        165    00:13:40.649 --> 00:13:43.310    TRAINED.        166    00:13:43.310 --> 00:13:46.190    YOU MUST LEAD.        167    00:13:46.190 --> 00:13:48.990    YOU MUST GET OUT THERE AND AS    DR.        168    00:13:48.990 --> 00:13:54.920    KING WOULD SAY, BE A    HEADLIGHT, NOT A TAILLIGHT!        169    00:13:54.920 --> 00:14:01.709    IT'S YOUR TIME, IT'S YOUR    CALLING.        170    00:14:01.709 --> 00:14:07.780    DURING THE 60s I GOT ARRESTED A    FEW TIMES, 40 TIMES!        171    00:14:07.780 --> 00:14:10.540    [LAUGHTER]    AND SINCE I'VE BEEN IN CONGRESS        172    00:14:10.540 --> 00:14:16.650    ANOTHER FIVE TIMES!        173    00:14:16.650 --> 00:14:23.570    [APPLAUSE]    AND I'M PROBABLY GOING TO GET        174    00:14:23.570 --> 00:14:27.550    ARRESTED AGAIN!        175    00:14:27.550 --> 00:14:30.600    MY PHILOSOPHY IS VERY SIMPLE,    WHEN YOU SEE SOMETHING THAT IS        176    00:14:30.600 --> 00:14:33.970    NOT RIGHT, NOT FAIR, NOT JUST,    STAND UP!        177    00:14:33.970 --> 00:14:34.970    SAY SOMETHING!        178    00:14:34.970 --> 00:14:41.750    SPEAK UP AND SPEAK OUT!        179    00:14:41.750 --> 00:14:47.779    [APPLAUSE]    WHEN I WAS GROWING UP AS A YOUNG        180    00:14:47.779 --> 00:14:55.330    BOY IN RURAL ALABAMA, 50 MILES    FROM MONTGOMERY, I HAD AN AUNT        181    00:14:55.330 --> 00:14:59.800    BY THE NAME OF SINEVA AND MY    AUNT LIVED IN A SHOTGUN HOUSE,        182    00:14:59.800 --> 00:15:03.260    HERE AT HARVARD YOU NEVER SEEN A    SHOTGUN HOUSE, YOU DON'T EVEN        183    00:15:03.260 --> 00:15:07.030    KNOW WHAT I'M TALKING ABOUT    [LAUGHTER]        184    00:15:07.030 --> 00:15:09.750    ONE WAY IN, ONE WAY OUT.        185    00:15:09.750 --> 00:15:15.529    WHAT IS A SHOTGUN HOUSE?        186    00:15:15.529 --> 00:15:20.380    OLD HOUSE, DIRT YARD.        187    00:15:20.380 --> 00:15:25.540    SOMETIMES MY AUNT SINEVA WOULD    GO OUT ON THE WEEKEND, FRIDAY OR        188    00:15:25.540 --> 00:15:32.810    SATURDAY, AND TAKE A BRUSH BROOM    MADE FROM DOGWOOD BRANCHES AND        189    00:15:32.810 --> 00:15:36.899    SWEEP THE YARD VERY CLEAN.        190    00:15:36.899 --> 00:15:44.640    ONE SATURDAY AFTERNOON FEW OF MY    BROTHERS AND SISTERS, COUSINS,        191    00:15:44.640 --> 00:15:49.350    ABOUT 15 OF US YOUNG CHILDREN    WERE PLAYING IN HER DIRT YARD.        192    00:15:49.350 --> 00:15:53.360    AND AN UNBELIEVABLE STORM CAME    UP.        193    00:15:53.360 --> 00:15:56.610    THE WIND STARTED BLOWING, THE    THUNDER STARTED ROLLING AND THE        194    00:15:56.610 --> 00:16:01.480    LIGHTNING STARTED FLASHING AND    SHE TOLD US TO COME IN.        195    00:16:01.480 --> 00:16:06.140    WE WENT IN.        196    00:16:06.140 --> 00:16:10.490    THE WIND CONTINUED TO BLOW, THE    THUNDER CONTINUED TO ROLL, THE        197    00:16:10.490 --> 00:16:16.810    LIGHTNING CONTINUED TO FLASH,    AND THE RAIN CONTINUED TO BEAT        198    00:16:16.810 --> 00:16:20.610    ON THIS OLD TIN ROOF OF THE    SHOTGUN HOUSE.        199    00:16:20.610 --> 00:16:21.959    AND WE CRIED AND CRIED.        200    00:16:21.959 --> 00:16:26.380    AND IN ONE CORNER OF THE OLD    HOUSE APPEARED TO BE LIFTING UP        201    00:16:26.380 --> 00:16:32.589    AND MY AUNT WALKED OVER TO THAT    SIDE TO HOLD THE HOUSE DOWN WITH        202    00:16:32.589 --> 00:16:33.589    HER BODY.        203    00:16:33.589 --> 00:16:35.480    WHEN THE OTHER CORNER APPEARED    TO BE LIFTING SHE HAD US WALK TO        204    00:16:35.480 --> 00:16:39.850    THAT CORNER, WE WERE CHILDREN    WALKING WITH THE WIND, BUT WE        205    00:16:39.850 --> 00:16:42.200    NEVER, EVER LEFT THE HOUSE!        206    00:16:42.200 --> 00:16:46.760    I SAY TO EACH OF YOU, EACH AND    EVERY ONE OF US, THE WIND MAY        207    00:16:46.760 --> 00:16:53.060    BLOW, THE THUNDER MAY ROLL, THE    LIGHTNING MAY FLASH AND THE RAIN        208    00:16:53.060 --> 00:16:59.790    MAY BEAT DOWN ON AN OLD HOUSE,    CALL IT A HOUSE OF HARVARD, CALL        209    00:16:59.790 --> 00:17:05.610    IT A HOUSE OF CAMBRIDGE, CALL IT    A HOUSE OF GLOUCESTER, CALL IT        210    00:17:05.610 --> 00:17:10.520    THE HOUSE OF WASHINGTON, OR    ALABAMA OR GEORGIA, WE ALL LIVE        211    00:17:10.520 --> 00:17:12.760    IN THE SAME HOUSE.        212    00:17:12.760 --> 00:17:17.829    WE ALL MUST HOLD OUR LITTLE    HOUSE DOWN.        213    00:17:17.829 --> 00:17:24.610    SO I SAY TO YOU: WALK WITH THE    WIND.        214    00:17:24.610 --> 00:17:30.090    LET THE SPIRIT OF HISTORY BE    YOUR GUIDE.        215    00:17:30.090 --> 00:17:35.690    THANK YOU VERY MUCH.        216    00:17:35.690 --> 00:17:41.030    [CHEERS & APPLAUSE]

title: Graduate Speaker Pete Davis | Harvard Commencement 2018
desc: Graduate Speaker Pete Davis addresses graduates at Harvard's 367th Commencement on May 24, 2018 at Tercentenary Theatre. For more information, visit https://news.harvard.edu/gazette/story/series/commencement-2018/.

title: Harvard President Drew Gilpin Faust Address | Harvard Commencement 2018
desc: Harvard President Drew Gilpin Faust addresses graduates at Harvard's 367th Commencement in her final address as president. For more information, visit https://news.harvard.edu/gazette/story/series/commencement-2018/.
