guaranteed; it was up    to them.        87    00:09:11.870 --> 00:09:20.140    Their careers and life goals had shifted to    embrace a much broader sense of responsibility        88    00:09:20.140 --> 00:09:27.360    extending beyond themselves to encompass an    obligation to a common good they had come        89    00:09:27.360 --> 00:09:32.510    to recognize might not survive without them.        90    00:09:32.510 --> 00:09:40.520    I thought of these students as something akin    to alchemistsâ€”confronting dark realities        91    00:09:40.520 --> 00:09:49.570    and forging a golden path that offered hopeâ€”to    themselves about their own lives, but to all        92    00:09:49.570 --> 00:09:59.000    of us as we imagine what these extraordinary    graduates will do with and for the damaged        93    00:09:59.000 --> 00:10:04.100    world we offer them as their inheritance.        94    00:10:04.100 --> 00:10:09.250    It would be impossible to be surrounded by    these students as they move through their        95    00:10:09.250 --> 00:10:17.680    time at Harvard without being filled with    hope about the future they will create.        96    00:10:17.680 --> 00:10:26.700    To paraphrase the Ed Schoolâ€™s Campaign slogan,    they are here learning to change the world.        97    00:10:26.700 --> 00:10:33.630    Building a more enlightened world is of course    the fundamental work of the faculty as well,        98    00:10:33.630 --> 00:10:39.130    and at the core of Harvardâ€™s identity as    a research university.        99    00:10:39.130 --> 00:10:46.180    The fundamental question we ask as we consider    appointing a professor is â€œWhat has this        100    00:10:46.180 --> 00:10:53.940    person done to alter and enhance our understanding    of the world?â€        101    00:10:53.940 --> 00:10:59.649    Perhaps they have revealed how the microbiome    works, or how international trade agreements        102    00:10:59.649 --> 00:11:09.110    affect economic prosperity, or how undocumented    students confront educational challenges.        103    00:11:09.110 --> 00:11:16.290    Perhaps theyâ€™ve unlocked ways to identify    the actual location of genes that cause schizophrenia,        104    00:11:16.290 --> 00:11:24.100    or have discovered how to engineer an exo-suit    to enable a person to walk.        105    00:11:24.100 --> 00:11:31.240    Harvard scholars explore history and literature    to help us understand tyranny; art to illuminate        106    00:11:31.240 --> 00:11:38.610    the foundations of justice; law and technology    to address assaults on fundamental assumptions        107    00:11:38.610 --> 00:11:41.440    about privacy.        108    00:11:41.440 --> 00:11:49.970    With its eye cast on creating a different    future, all of this work is founded in hopeâ€”of        109    00:11:49.970 --> 00:11:57.000    seeing something more clearly, of influencing    others to change their understanding and perhaps        110    00:11:57.000 --> 00:11:59.860    even their actions.        111    00:11:59.860 --> 00:12:07.529    We are by definition a community of idealists,    thinking beyond the present and the status        112    00:12:07.529 --> 00:12:16.460    quo to imagine how and when things could be    different, could be otherwise.        113    00:12:16.460 --> 00:12:23.209    The privilege of interacting with Harvardâ€™s    remarkable students and faculty, and the dedicated        114    00:12:23.209 --> 00:12:30.730    staff who support their work has uplifted    me every day for the past eleven years.        115    00:12:30.730 --> 00:12:36.779    It would be next to impossible not to believe    in the future they are so intent to build.        116    00:12:36.779 --> 00:12:44.660    But there is another way that Harvard fills    me with hope, and that is the way we as a        117    00:12:44.660 --> 00:12:51.050    communityâ€”living and working together within    these wallsâ€”are endeavoring ourselves to        118    00:12:51.050 --> 00:12:57.610    grapple with the challenging forces dividing    and threatening the worldâ€”forces like climate        119    00:12:57.610 --> 00:13:05.149    change, or the divisiveness that poisons our    society and polity, the undermining of facts        120    00:13:05.149 --> 00:13:10.730    and rational discourse, the chilling of free    speech.        121    00:13:10.730 --> 00:13:17.200    We might in some ways see the work we have    undertaken together on sustainability as emblematic        122    00:13:17.200 --> 00:13:18.810    of these wider efforts.        123    00:13:18.810 --> 00:13:23.860    We have come to consider ourselves a living    laboratory.        124    00:13:23.860 --> 00:13:29.100    Our research and engagement on environmental    issues of course stretches well beyond our        125    00:13:29.100 --> 00:13:35.680    walls: our faculty, for example, have played    critical roles in forging international climate        126    00:13:35.680 --> 00:13:42.950    agreements, have engineered innovative ways    to create and store renewable energy, have        127    00:13:42.950 --> 00:13:49.649    influenced regulatory frameworks from Washington    to Beijing, have explored the searing impact        128    00:13:49.649 --> 00:13:52.860    of climate change on health.        129    00:13:52.860 --> 00:13:59.660    But at the same time we have endeavored to    make our own community a model for what might        130    00:13:59.660 --> 00:14:06.640    be possibleâ€”what we might hope for as we    imagine the future.        131    00:14:06.640 --> 00:14:15.110    We have reduced our greenhouse gas emissions    by 30%, our trash by 44%; we produce 1.5 megawatts        132    00:14:15.110 --> 00:14:19.649    of solar energyâ€”enough to fuel 300 homes.        133    00:14:19.649 --> 00:14:24.860    We have programs experimenting with healthy    building materials, green cleaning, and food        134    00:14:24.860 --> 00:14:32.130    waste, and we have constructed HouseZero,    an energy neutral structure that is essentially        135    00:14:32.130 --> 00:14:39.500    an enormous computer generating data about    every aspect of its operation and design,        136    00:14:39.500 --> 00:14:45.100    making information available to others as    they build for the future.        137    00:14:45.100 --> 00:14:50.779    We seek to be a living experiment in other    ways as well.        138    00:14:50.779 --> 00:14:58.490    We gather here in Cambridge, face to face    in a residential educational setting because        139    00:14:58.490 --> 00:15:04.860    we regard this very community as an educational    machine.        140    00:15:04.860 --> 00:15:10.490    I have often observed that Harvard is likely    the most diverse environment in which most        141    00:15:10.490 --> 00:15:13.830    of our students have ever lived.        142    00:15:13.830 --> 00:15:20.080    We endeavor to attract talented individuals    from the widest possible range of backgrounds,        143    00:15:20.080 --> 00:15:28.630    experiences and interests, the broadest diversity    of geographic origins, socio-economic circumstances,        144    00:15:28.630 --> 00:15:36.730    ethnicities, races, religions, gender identities,    sexual orientations, political perspectives.        145    00:15:36.730 --> 00:15:44.380    And we ask students to learn from these differences,    to teach one anotherâ€”and to teach us as        146    00:15:44.380 --> 00:15:49.640    wellâ€”with the variety of who they are and    what they bring.        147    00:15:49.640 --> 00:15:52.550    This isnâ€™t easy.        148    00:15:52.550 --> 00:15:58.600    It requires individuals to question long-held    assumptions, to open their minds and their        149    00:15:58.600 --> 00:16:06.010    hearts to ideas and arguments that may seem    not just unfamiliar, but even disturbing and        150    00:16:06.010 --> 00:16:08.240    disorienting.        151    00:16:08.240 --> 00:16:14.240    And it is an experiment that becomes ever    more difficult in an increasingly polarized        152    00:16:14.240 --> 00:16:22.209    social and political environment in which    expressions of hatred, bigotry, and divisiveness        153    00:16:22.209 --> 00:16:26.920    seem not just permitted but encouraged.        154    00:16:26.920 --> 00:16:34.829    But in spite of these challenges all around    us, we at Harvard strive to be enriched, not        155    00:16:34.829 --> 00:16:39.100    divided by our differences.        156    00:16:39.100 --> 00:16:46.269    To sustain this vision of an educational community,    we must be a living laboratory in another        157    00:16:46.269 --> 00:16:49.020    sense as well.        158    00:16:49.020 --> 00:17:07.709    We must be a place where facts matter, where    reasoned         159    00:17:07.709 --> 00:17:13.979    and respectful discourse and debate serve    as arbiters of truth.        160    00:17:13.979 --> 00:17:20.100    There has been much recent criticism of universities    for not being sufficiently open to differing        161    00:17:20.100 --> 00:17:21.829    viewpoints.        162    00:17:21.829 --> 00:17:27.899    Protecting and nourishing free speech is for    us a fundamental commitment, and one that        163    00:17:27.899 --> 00:17:34.830    demands constant attention and vigilance,    especially in a time of sharp political and        164    00:17:34.830 --> 00:17:37.770    social polarization.        165    00:17:37.770 --> 00:17:49.100    The uncontrolledâ€”and uncontrollableâ€”cacophony    that defines a university means we will inevitably        166    00:17:49.100 --> 00:17:55.950    sometimes fall short; we cannot always guarantee    that every member of this community listens        167    00:17:55.950 --> 00:17:59.360    generously to every other.        168    00:17:59.360 --> 00:18:04.200    But that must simply motivate us to redouble    our efforts.        169    00:18:04.200 --> 00:18:10.769    Silencing ideas or basking in comfortable    intellectual orthodoxy independent of facts        170    00:18:10.769 --> 00:18:24.090    and evidence blocks our access to new and    better ideas.        171    00:18:24.090 --> 00:18:30.509    We must be dedicated to the belief that truth    cannot simply be asserted or claimed but must        172    00:18:30.509 --> 00:18:39.149    be established with evidence and tested with    argument.        173    00:18:39.149 --> 00:18:46.919    Truth serves as inspiration and aspiration    in all we do; it pulls us toward the future        174    00:18:46.919 --> 00:18:53.479    and its possibilities for seeing more clearly,    understanding more fully, and improving ourselves        175    00:18:53.479 --> 00:18:55.370    and the world.        176    00:18:55.370 --> 00:18:59.799    Its pursuit is fueled by hope.        177    00:18:59.799 --> 00:19:06.110    Hope joins with truth as the as the very essence    of a university.        178    00:19:06.110 --> 00:19:15.590    And so I come back to hopeâ€”the hope implicit    in our efforts to model a different way for        179    00:19:15.590 --> 00:19:23.289    humans to live and work together, the hope    in the ideas and discoveries that are the        180    00:19:23.289 --> 00:19:32.970    currency we trade in, the hope in the bright    futures of those who graduate today.        181    00:19:32.970 --> 00:19:39.450    Yet as I step down from my responsibilities    as Harvard president, I am keenly aware of        182    00:19:39.450 --> 00:19:44.299    another of hopeâ€™s fundamental attributes.        183    00:19:44.299 --> 00:19:53.789    It implies work still unfinished, aspirations    not yet matched by achievement, possibilities        184    00:19:53.789 --> 00:19:57.389    yet to be seized and realized.        185    00:19:57.389 --> 00:20:00.789    Hope is a challenge.        186    00:20:00.789 --> 00:20:07.350    I think of the words the beloved late crew    coach Harry Parker once spoke to a rowerâ€”words        187    00:20:07.350 --> 00:20:16.109    I quoted often during the campaign: â€œThis    is what you can be.        188    00:20:16.109 --> 00:20:20.109    Do you want to be that?â€        189    00:20:20.109 --> 00:20:26.330    These are the words and the message I would    like to leave with Harvard.        190    00:20:26.330 --> 00:20:27.879    The work is unfinished.        191    00:20:27.879 --> 00:20:37.779    The job remains still to be done in times    that make it perhaps more difficult than ever.        192    00:20:37.779 --> 00:20:46.270    May we continue to challenge ourselves with    the hope of all we can be and with the unwavering        193    00:20:46.270 --> 00:20:50.529    determination to be that.        194    00:20:50.529 --> 00:20:59.849    May Harvard be as wise as it is smart    As restless as it is proud        195    00:20:59.849 --> 00:21:07.139    As bold as it is thoughtful    As new as it is old        196    00:21:07.139 --> 00:21:21.189    As good as it is great.

title: Gov. John Kasich's remarks at Harvard Kennedy School Commencement 2018
desc: Ohio Governor John Kasich addresses the Class of 2018 at Harvard Kennedy School. Recorded May 24, 2018.
speech_raw: 1    00:00:00.192 --> 00:00:02.530    (audience applauding)        2    00:00:02.530 --> 00:00:05.250    Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome.        3    00:00:05.250 --> 00:00:09.380    It is my great pleasure    to be presiding this year        4    00:00:09.380 --> 00:00:11.850    over my third Commencement        5    00:00:11.850 --> 00:00:14.860    as the Dean of Harvard Kennedy School.        6    00:00:14.860 --> 00:00:18.352    To the class of 2018, congratulations.        7    00:00:18.352 --> 00:00:22.602    (audience cheering and applauding)        8    00:00:31.610 -->    24    00:01:25.610 --> 00:01:29.023    that you are here to join    this celebration with us.        25    00:01:29.960 --> 00:01:32.670    Today we are gathered    for the Kennedy School        26 Governor Kasich from    the great state of Ohio.        29    00:01:41.658 --> 00:01:45.908    (audience cheering and applauding)        30    00:01:51.280 --> 00:01:53.780    Governor Kasich has had    a distinguished career        31    00:01:53.780 --> 00:01:57.390    in public service at both    the national and state levels        32    00:01:57.390 --> 00:02:00.300    in the United States and Ingersoll and as if I was        807    00:45:34.869 --> 00:45:36.250    supposed to know he said remember what        808    00:45:36.250 --> 00:45:38.050    Plato said Joe everything what in the        809    00:45:38.050 --> 00:45:40.530    hell's that about        810    00:45:41.680 --> 00:45:44.540    Plato said dependently good people pay        811    00:45:44.540 --> 00:45:46.580    for not being involved in politics is        812    00:45:46.580 --> 00:45:49.730    being governed by people worse than        813    00:45:49.730 --> 00:45:52.420    themselves let me say that again the        814    00:45:52.420 --> 00:45:56.150    penalty good people pay for not being        815    00:45:56.150 --> 00:45:58.370    involved with politics is being governed        816    00:45:58.370 --> 00:46:00.620    by people worse than themselves so you        817    00:46:00.620 --> 00:46:03.440    have to engage you have to be involved        818    00:46:03.440 --> 00:46:06.580    even in this dirty business of politics        819    00:46:06.580 --> 00:46:12.040    you have to for your own safety sake and        820    00:46:12.040 --> 00:46:15.950    I have no doubt you will because you        821    00:46:15.950 --> 00:46:18.740    must thank you for having me god bless        822    00:46:18.740 --> 00:46:22.000    you all and may God protect our        823    00:46:45.349 --> 00:46:47.410    you

title: Harvard President Drew Gilpin Faust Address | Harvard Commencement 2017
desc: Harvard President Drew Gilpin Faust addresses graduates at Harvard's 366th Commencement on May 26, 2017 at Tercentenary Theatre. For more information, visit http://news.harvard.edu/gazette/story/topic/commencement-2017/.
speech_raw: 1    00:00:11.490 --> 00:00:16.360    Good afternoon. My remarks at this moment        2    00:00:16.360 --> 00:00:18.310    in our commencement rituals are        3    00:00:18.310 --> 00:00:19.990    officially titled        4    00:00:19.990 --> 00:00:23.740    "A report to the alumni." The first time I        5    00:00:23.740 --> 00:00:27.460    delivered them in 2008 I was the only        6    00:00:27.460 --> 00:00:30.460    obstacle between all of you and JK        7    00:00:30.460 --> 00:00:35.470    Rowling. I looked out on a sea of eager        8    00:00:35.470 --> 00:00:38.260    children, costumed Dumbledores, and        9    00:00:38.260 --> 00:00:41.710    Quidditch brooms waving impatiently in        10    00:00:41.710 --> 00:00:45.900    the air. Today you await Mark Zuckerberg        11    00:00:45.900 --> 00:00:49.590    whose wizardry takes a different form        12    00:00:49.590 --> 00:00:53.160    one that has changed the world and        13    00:00:53.160 --> 00:00:55.540    although he doesn't seem to have        14    00:00:55.540 --> 00:00:58.540    inspired an outbreak of hoodies, we        15    00:00:58.540 --> 00:01:01.270    certainly do have some costumes in this        16    00:01:01.270 --> 00:01:03.850    audience today; I see we're now handing        17    00:01:03.850 --> 00:01:09.670    out blankets. This is a day of joy and        18    00:01:09.670 --> 00:01:13.509    celebration of happy endings and new        19    00:01:13.509 --> 00:01:17.369    beginnings, of families and friends, of        20    00:01:17.369 --> 00:01:21.969    achievements and hopes, it is also a day        21    00:01:21.969 --> 00:01:25.209    when we as a university perform our most        22    00:01:25.209 --> 00:01:29.200    important annual ritual, affirming once        23    00:01:29.200 --> 00:01:32.609    again the purposes that animate us and        24    00:01:32.609 --> 00:01:37.380    the values that direct and inspire us. I        25    00:01:37.380 --> 00:01:40.240    want to speak today about one of the        26    00:01:40.240 --> 00:01:42.999    most important and, in recent months, most        27    00:01:42.999 --> 00:01:47.499    contested of these values. It is one that        28    00:01:47.499 --> 00:01:50.249    has provoked debate, dissent,        29    00:01:50.249 --> 00:01:53.380    confrontation, and even violence on        30    00:01:53.380 --> 00:01:57.099    campuses across the country, and one that        31    00:01:57.099 --> 00:01:59.319    has attracted widespread public        32    00:01:59.319 --> 00:02:03.789    attention and criticism. I am of course        33    00:02:03.789 --> 00:02:07.500    talking about issues of free speech on        34    00:02:07.500 --> 00:02:11.439    university campuses. The meaning and        35    00:02:11.440 --> 00:02:12.720    limits of free        36    00:02:12.720 --> 00:02:15.820    speech are questions deeply embedded in        37    00:02:15.829 --> 00:02:20.000    our legal system. In interpretations of        38    00:02:20.000 --> 00:02:21.469    the First Amendment and its        39    00:02:21.469 --> 00:02:25.370    applications. I am no constitutional        40    00:02:25.370 --> 00:02:25.849    lawyer,        41    00:02:25.849 --> 00:02:29.569    indeed no lawyer at all, and I do not        42    00:02:29.569 --> 00:02:31.849    intend in my brief remarks today to        43    00:02:31.849 --> 00:02:35.629    address complex legal doctrines; nor        44    00:02:35.629 --> 00:02:38.170    clearly can I, in a few brief minutes,        45    00:02:38.170 --> 00:02:42.260    take on even a fraction of the arguments        46    00:02:42.260 --> 00:02:45.400    that have been advanced on this issue.        47    00:02:45.400 --> 00:02:48.950    Instead I speak as one who has been a        48    00:02:48.950 --> 00:02:51.669    university president for a decade in        49    00:02:51.669 --> 00:02:56.510    order to raise three questions: first,        50    00:02:56.510 --> 00:03:00.469    why is free speech so important to and        51    00:03:00.469 --> 00:03:05.959    at universities? Second, why does it seem        52    00:03:05.959 --> 00:03:09.609    under special challenge right now? And        53    00:03:09.609 --> 00:03:13.579    third, how might we better address these        54    00:03:13.579 --> 00:03:17.000    challenges by moving beyond just        55    00:03:17.000 --> 00:03:20.150    defensively protecting free speech which,        56    00:03:20.150 --> 00:03:24.400    of course, we must do, to actively and        57    00:03:24.400 --> 00:03:28.489    affirmatively enabling it and nurturing        58    00:03:28.489 --> 00:03:32.419    environments in which it can thrive? So        59    00:03:32.419 --> 00:03:36.199    first why is free speech so important to        60    00:03:36.199 --> 00:03:40.220    and at universities? This is a question I        61    00:03:40.220 --> 00:03:41.689    took up with the newly arrived        62    00:03:41.689 --> 00:03:44.150    first-year students in the college when        63    00:03:44.150 --> 00:03:46.699    I welcomed them at convocation last fall.        64    00:03:46.699 --> 00:03:50.329    For centuries I told them universities        65    00:03:50.329 --> 00:03:51.979    have been environments in which        66    00:03:51.979 --> 00:03:55.329    knowledge has been discovered, collected        67    00:03:55.329 --> 00:03:59.150    studied, debated, expanded, changed, and        68    00:03:59.150 --> 00:04:02.509    advanced through the power of rational        69    00:04:02.509 --> 00:04:07.269    argument and exchange. We pursued truth        70    00:04:07.269 --> 00:04:11.080    unrelentingly but we must never be so        71    00:04:11.080 --> 00:04:14.640    complacent as to believe we have unerringly        72    00:04:14.640 --> 00:04:18.120    attained it. Veritas is        73    00:04:18.130 --> 00:04:22.580    inspiration and aspiration. We assume        74    00:04:22.580 --> 00:04:25.370    there is always more to know and        75    00:04:25.370 --> 00:04:26.300    discover,        76    00:04:26.300 --> 00:04:29.720    so we open ourselves to challenge and        77    00:04:29.720 --> 00:04:34.100    change. We must always be ready to be        78    00:04:34.100 --> 00:04:37.400    wrong. So being part of a university        79    00:04:37.400 --> 00:04:41.470    community requires courage and humility.        80    00:04:41.470 --> 00:04:44.720    Universities must be places open to the        81    00:04:44.720 --> 00:04:48.010    kind of debate that can change ideas, and        82    00:04:48.010 --> 00:04:50.870    committed to standards of reason and        83    00:04:50.870 --> 00:04:53.560    evidence that form the basis for        84    00:04:53.560 --> 00:04:58.280    evaluating them. Silencing ideas or        85    00:04:58.280 --> 00:05:01.370    basking in intellectual orthodoxy        86    00:05:01.370 --> 00:05:04.540    independent of facts and evidence        87    00:05:04.540 --> 00:05:07.669    impedes our access to new and better        88    00:05:07.669 --> 00:05:11.510    ideas, and it inhibits a full and        89    00:05:11.510 --> 00:05:15.950    considered rejection of bad ones. From at        90    00:05:15.950 --> 00:05:18.890    least the time of Galileo we can see how        91    00:05:18.890 --> 00:05:22.850    repressing seemingly heretical ideas has        92    00:05:22.850 --> 00:05:25.220    blinded societies and nations        93    00:05:25.220 --> 00:05:28.639    to enhance knowledge and understanding        94    00:05:28.639 --> 00:05:32.360    on which progress depends. Far more        95    00:05:32.360 --> 00:05:35.600    recently we can see here at Harvard how        96    00:05:35.600 --> 00:05:37.310    our inattentiveness        97    00:05:37.310 --> 00:05:40.550    to the power and appeal of conservative        98    00:05:40.550 --> 00:05:43.400    voices left much of our community        99    00:05:43.400 --> 00:05:47.090    astonished, blindsided by the outcome of        100    00:05:47.090 --> 00:05:51.350    last fall's election. We must work to        101    00:05:51.350 --> 00:05:54.260    ensure that universities do not become        102    00:05:54.260 --> 00:05:57.130    bubbles isolated from the concerns and        103    00:05:57.130 --> 00:06:00.440    discourse of the society that surrounds        104    00:06:00.440 --> 00:06:04.190    them. Universities must model a        105    00:06:04.190 --> 00:06:06.440    commitment to the notion that truth        106    00:06:06.440 --> 00:06:10.000    cannot simply be claimed, but must be        107    00:06:10.000 --> 00:06:13.550    established. Established through reasoned        108    00:06:13.550 --> 00:06:17.030    argument, assessment, and even sometimes        109    00:06:17.030 --> 00:06:19.789    uncomfortable challenges that provide        110    00:06:19.789 --> 00:06:23.390    the foundation for truth. The legitimacy        111    00:06:23.390 --> 00:06:26.660    of universities claim to be sources        112    00:06:26.660 --> 00:06:31.039    and validators of fact depends on our        113    00:06:31.039 --> 00:06:34.729    willingness to actively and vigorously defend        114    00:06:34.729 --> 00:06:38.390    those facts. And we must remember that        115    00:06:38.390 --> 00:06:39.260    limiting        116    00:06:39.260 --> 00:06:42.530    some speech opens the dangerous        117    00:06:42.530 --> 00:06:45.260    possibility that the speech that is        118    00:06:45.260 --> 00:06:49.480    ultimately censored may be our own. If        119    00:06:49.480 --> 00:06:52.310    some words are to be treated as        120    00:06:52.310 --> 00:06:55.210    equivalent to physical violence, and        121    00:06:55.210 --> 00:06:59.510    silenced or even prosecuted, who is to        122    00:06:59.510 --> 00:07:04.190    decide which words? Freedom of expression        123    00:07:04.190 --> 00:07:06.920    as Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes        124    00:07:06.920 --> 00:07:10.820    famously said long ago, protects free        125    00:07:10.820 --> 00:07:14.180    thought for those who agree with us, but        126    00:07:14.180 --> 00:07:16.220    excuse me, not only free thought        127    00:07:16.220 --> 00:07:19.190    for those who agree with us, but freedom        128    00:07:19.190 --> 00:07:23.390    for the thought we hate. We need to hear        129    00:07:23.390 --> 00:07:26.420    those hateful ideas so our society is        130    00:07:26.420 --> 00:07:30.550    fully equipped to oppose and defeat them.        131    00:07:30.550 --> 00:07:32.120    Over the years,        132    00:07:32.120 --> 00:07:34.490    differences about the implementation of        133    00:07:34.490 --> 00:07:36.680    the university's free speech principles        134    00:07:36.680 --> 00:07:40.030    have often provoked controversy and we        135    00:07:40.030 --> 00:07:43.880    haven't always gotten it right. As long        136    00:07:43.880 --> 00:07:48.170    ago as 1939, an invitation from a student        137    00:07:48.170 --> 00:07:50.630    group to the head of the American        138    00:07:50.630 --> 00:07:53.890    Communist Party generated protests, and        139    00:07:53.890 --> 00:07:56.570    the invitation was ultimately cancelled        140    00:07:56.570 --> 00:08:00.350    by the corporation. Bertrand Russell's        141    00:08:00.350 --> 00:08:02.720    appointment as William James lecturer        142    00:08:02.720 --> 00:08:05.030    just a year later divided the        143    00:08:05.030 --> 00:08:08.150    corporation, but president Conan broke        144    00:08:08.150 --> 00:08:11.930    the tie and Russell came. Campus        145    00:08:11.930 --> 00:08:14.630    conflicts over invited speakers are        146    00:08:14.630 --> 00:08:18.710    hardly new, yet the vehements with which        147    00:08:18.710 --> 00:08:21.020    these issues have been debated in recent        148    00:08:21.020 --> 00:08:24.140    months, not just on campuses but in the        149    00:08:24.140 --> 00:08:27.230    broader public sphere, suggest there is        150    00:08:27.230 --> 00:08:30.520    something distinctive about this moment.        151    00:08:30.520 --> 00:08:33.800    Certainly these controversies reflect a        152    00:08:33.800 --> 00:08:36.790    highly polarized political and social        153    00:08:36.790 --> 00:08:40.070    environment, perhaps the most divisive        154    00:08:40.070 --> 00:08:44.120    since the era of the civil war. And in        155    00:08:44.120 --> 00:08:46.810    these already fractious circumstances,        156    00:08:46.810 --> 00:08:50.000    free speech debates have provided a        157    00:08:50.000 --> 00:08:52.130    fertile substrate        158    00:08:52.130 --> 00:08:54.560    into which anger and disagreement could        159    00:08:54.560 --> 00:08:57.680    be planted to nourish partisan outrage        160    00:08:57.680 --> 00:09:01.550    and generate media clickbait. But that        161    00:09:01.550 --> 00:09:05.410    is only a partial explanation.        162    00:09:05.589 --> 00:09:08.089    Universities themselves have changed        163    00:09:08.089 --> 00:09:11.180    dramatically in recent years, reaching        164    00:09:11.180 --> 00:09:13.190    beyond their traditional largely        165    00:09:13.190 --> 00:09:16.759    homogeneous populations to become more        166    00:09:16.759 --> 00:09:19.089    diverse than perhaps any other        167    00:09:19.089 --> 00:09:22.130    institution in which Americans find        168    00:09:22.130 --> 00:09:25.180    themselves living together. Once        169    00:09:25.180 --> 00:09:29.089    overwhelmingly white, male, Protestant, and        170    00:09:29.089 --> 00:09:33.139    upper-class, Harvard College is now half        171    00:09:33.139 --> 00:09:37.100    female, majority minority, religiously        172    00:09:37.100 --> 00:09:40.940    pluralistic with nearly 60% of students        173    00:09:40.940 --> 00:09:45.790    able to attend because of financial aid.        174    00:09:54.100 --> 00:09:56.959    Fifteen percent are the first in their        175    00:09:56.959 --> 00:10:05.209    families to go to college. Many of        176    00:10:05.209 --> 00:10:07.730    our students struggle to feel full        177    00:10:07.730 --> 00:10:11.390    members of this community: a community in        178    00:10:11.390 --> 00:10:14.360    which people like them have so recently        179    00:10:14.360 --> 00:10:18.829    arrived. They seek evidence and assurance        180    00:10:18.829 --> 00:10:21.890    that to borrow the title of a powerful        181    00:10:21.890 --> 00:10:24.709    theatrical piece created by a group of        182    00:10:24.709 --> 00:10:27.769    our African-American students, evidence        183    00:10:27.769 --> 00:10:31.810    and assurance that they too are Harvard.        184    00:10:31.810 --> 00:10:35.390    The price of our commitment to freedom        185    00:10:35.390 --> 00:10:39.290    of speech is paid disproportionately by        186    00:10:39.290 --> 00:10:43.519    these students. For them free speech has        187    00:10:43.519 --> 00:10:46.760    not infrequently included enduring a        188    00:10:46.760 --> 00:10:49.490    questioning of their abilities, their        189    00:10:49.490 --> 00:10:53.180    humanity, their morality, their very        190    00:10:53.180 --> 00:10:57.200    legitimacy here. Our values and our        191    00:10:57.200 --> 00:10:59.390    theory of education rest on the        192    00:10:59.390 --> 00:11:01.459    assumption that members of our community        193    00:11:01.459 --> 00:11:04.250    will take the risk of speaking and will        194    00:11:04.250 --> 00:11:07.100    actively compete in our wild rumpus of        195    00:11:07.100 --> 00:11:10.880    argument and ideas. It requires them as        196    00:11:10.880 --> 00:11:14.120    well to be fearless in face of argument        197    00:11:14.120 --> 00:11:17.560    or challenge or even verbal insult and        198    00:11:17.560 --> 00:11:21.800    it expects that fearlessness even when        199    00:11:21.800 --> 00:11:24.350    the challenge is directed to the very        200    00:11:24.350 --> 00:11:28.570    identity, race, religion, gender, ethnicity,        201    00:11:28.570 --> 00:11:32.779    sexual orientation, nationality, that may        202    00:11:32.779 --> 00:11:35.240    have made them uncertain about their        203    00:11:35.240 --> 00:11:38.440    right to be here in the first place.        204    00:11:38.440 --> 00:11:41.920    Demonstrating such fearlessness is hard.        205    00:11:41.920 --> 00:11:44.959    No one should be mocked as a snowflake        206    00:11:44.959 --> 00:11:50.380    for finding it so. Hard,        207    00:11:53.670 --> 00:11:58.889    hard but important and attainable.        208    00:11:58.889 --> 00:12:01.629    Attainable, we believe, for every member        209    00:12:01.629 --> 00:12:05.319    of our community. But the price of free        210    00:12:05.319 --> 00:12:08.230    speech cannot be charged just to those        211    00:12:08.230 --> 00:12:12.819    most likely to become its target. We must        212    00:12:12.819 --> 00:12:15.850    support and empower the voices of all        213    00:12:15.850 --> 00:12:19.179    the members of our community and nurture        214    00:12:19.179 --> 00:12:22.059    the courage and humility that our        215    00:12:22.059 --> 00:12:24.699    commitment to unfettered debate demands        216    00:12:24.699 --> 00:12:27.759    from all of us. And that courage means        217    00:12:27.759 --> 00:12:31.209    not only resilience in face of challenge        218    00:12:31.209 --> 00:12:34.720    or attack, but strength to speak out        219    00:12:34.720 --> 00:12:38.410    against injustices directed at others        220    00:12:38.410 --> 00:12:42.910    as well. Free speech does not just happen        221    00:12:42.910 --> 00:12:45.759    and require intervention when it is        222    00:12:45.759 --> 00:12:49.420    impeded. It is not about the freedom to        223    00:12:49.420 --> 00:12:51.910    out-shout others while everyone has        224    00:12:51.910 --> 00:12:55.629    their fingers in their ears. For free        225    00:12:55.629 --> 00:12:57.819    speech to flourish, we must build an        226    00:12:57.819 --> 00:12:59.769    environment where everyone takes        227    00:12:59.769 --> 00:13:02.860    responsibility for the right not just to        228    00:13:02.860 --> 00:13:06.269    speak, but to hear and be heard,        229    00:13:06.269 --> 00:13:08.860    where everyone assumes the        230    00:13:08.860 --> 00:13:11.170    responsibility to treat others with        231    00:13:11.170 --> 00:13:14.829    dignity and respect. It requires not just        232    00:13:14.829 --> 00:13:17.740    speakers, but in the words of James Ryan,        233    00:13:17.740 --> 00:13:20.519    Dean of our Graduate School of Education,        234    00:13:20.519 --> 00:13:24.429    generous listeners. Amidst the current        235    00:13:24.429 --> 00:13:27.249    soul-searching about free speech, we need        236    00:13:27.249 --> 00:13:30.369    to devote more attention to establishing        237    00:13:30.369 --> 00:13:32.649    the conditions in which everyone's        238    00:13:32.649 --> 00:13:36.990    speech is encouraged and taken seriously.        239    00:13:36.990 --> 00:13:40.029    Ensuring freedom of speech is not just        240    00:13:40.029 --> 00:13:43.269    about allowing speech; it is about        241    00:13:43.269 --> 00:13:45.790    actively creating a community where        242    00:13:45.790 --> 00:13:48.720    everyone can contribute and flourish; a        243    00:13:48.720 --> 00:13:51.939    community where argument is relished, not        244    00:13:51.939 --> 00:13:55.149    feared. Freedom of speech is not just        245    00:13:55.149 --> 00:13:59.069    freedom from censorship, it is freedom to        246    00:13:59.069 --> 00:14:02.350    actively join the debate as a full        247    00:14:02.350 --> 00:14:03.300    participant.        248    00:14:03.300 --> 00:14:06.699    It is about creating a context in which        249    00:14:06.699 --> 00:14:10.959    genuine debate can happen. Talk a lot I        250    00:14:10.959 --> 00:14:14.829    urged the class of 2020 last fall; listen        251    00:14:14.829 --> 00:14:15.519    more.        252    00:14:15.519 --> 00:14:19.089    Don't stand safely on the sidelines; take        253    00:14:19.089 --> 00:14:21.970    the risk of being wrong: it is the best        254    00:14:21.970 --> 00:14:25.329    way to learn and grow. And build a        255    00:14:25.329 --> 00:14:28.089    culture of generous listening so that        256    00:14:28.089 --> 00:14:31.120    others may be emboldened to take risks        257    00:14:31.120 --> 00:14:35.110    too. A community in a shared search for        258    00:14:35.110 --> 00:14:38.319    Veritas: that is the ideal for which        259    00:14:38.319 --> 00:14:42.129    Harvard must strive. We need it now more        260    00:14:42.129 --> 00:14:46.290    than ever. Thank you.

title: Harvard Female Orator Bessie Zhang | Harvard Commencement 2017
desc: Female Orator Bessie Zhang addresses graduating seniors at Harvardâ€™s Senior Class Day ceremony on May 24, 2017 at Tercentenary Theatre. For more information, visit http://news.harvard.edu/gazette/story/topic/commencement-2017/.

the fire pit to stay warm        4    00:00:20.810 --> 00:00:22.920    around the circle set several        5    00:00:22.920 --> 00:00:25.859    bright-eyed incoming freshmen including        6    00:00:25.859 --> 00:00:29.369    myself we shivered slightly in the        7    00:00:29.369 --> 00:00:32.099    evening chill and I pulled my jacket        8    00:00:32.099 --> 00:00:35.670 title: Commencement 2017: Dean Michelle Williams address
desc: As you step into this next chapter, each one of you will face rare challengesâ€”but also opportunities. Events have shocked us into actionâ€”and into a new solidarity and sense of shared mission. This is a resource of tremendous power, ours to use or squander.        If there is one quality these times demand it is agility, a word that I have thought of a lot during this academic year. Agility means for me and for many of us the capacity to see openings and quickly act on themâ€”and I witnessed you all being agile during times of distress during this academic year. Agility also means to think creatively, to leverage circumstancesâ€”and I saw all you respond with great agility during this academic year.        To this end, I urge you to seek common ground with those you may be tempted to write off. In a world as polarized as ours is today, this can feel daunting. It is daunting. But I also think it is essential.        -- Harvard Chan Dean Michelle Williams

title: Lead With Grace: Dean James Ryan's 2017 Commencement Address
desc: The prepared remarks of Dean James Ryan for the 2017 HGSE Presentation of Diplomas and Certificates.        Transcription Available Here: http://www.gse.harvard.edu/news/17/05/lead-grace            --        Harvard Graduate School of Education Website: http://www.gse.harvard.edu    Follow us on Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/harvardeducation/    Like us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/HarvardEducation/    Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/hgse        Since its founding in 1920, the Harvard Graduate School of Education has been training leaders to transform education in the United States and around the globe. Today, our faculty, students, and alumni are studying and solving the most critical challenges facing education: student assessment, the achievement gap, urban education, and teacher shortages, to name just a few. Our work is shaping how people teach, learn, and lead in schools and colleges as well as in after-school programs, high-tech companies, and international organizations. The HGSE community is pushing the frontiers of education, and the effects of our entrepreneurship are improving the world.

title: Nicholas Burns at Harvard Kennedy School 2024 Graduation Address
desc: Remarks by Nicholas Burns, the U.S. ambassador to the Peopleâ€™s Republic of China, at Harvard Kennedy School on May 22, 2024.     ---    About Harvard Kennedy School:        The John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University is a graduate and professional school that brings together students, scholars, and practitioners who combine thought and action to make the world a better place.        Our mission is to improve public policy and public leadership across the United States and around the world so that people can lead safer, freer, and more prosperous lives. Harvard Kennedy School teaches current and future leaders the skills they need to effectively advance the public purpose in the public, nonprofit, and private sectors. Our renowned faculty and trailblazing research centers pioneer bold new ideas. And as the most international school at Harvard, we convene global leaders in the Forum, host visiting experts in the classroom, and attract a diverse community of faculty, students, and staff.

title: James Ryan's 2016 Commencement Speech
desc: Dean James Ryan's remarks at the 2016 HGSE Presentation of Diplomas and Certificates. Read here: http://www.gse.harvard.edu/news/16/05/good-questions            --        Harvard Graduate School of Education Website: http://www.gse.harvard.edu    Follow us on Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/harvardeducation/    Like us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/HarvardEducation/    Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/hgse        Since its founding in 1920, the Harvard Graduate School of Education has been training leaders to transform education in the United States and around the globe. Today, our faculty, students, and alumni are studying and solving the most critical challenges facing education: student assessment, the achievement gap, urban education, and teacher shortages, to name just a few. Our work is shaping how people teach, learn, and lead in schools and colleges as well as in after-school programs, high-tech companies, and international organizations. The HGSE community is pushing the frontiers of education, and the effects of our entrepreneurship are improving the world.

title: Dean Jim Ryan's 2015 Harvard Commencement Address
desc: May 28th, 2015            --        Harvard Graduate School of Education Website: http://www.gse.harvard.edu    Follow us on Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/harvardeducation/    Like us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/HarvardEducation/    Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/hgse        Since its founding in 1920, the Harvard Graduate School of Education has been training leaders to transform education in the United States and around the globe. Today, our faculty, students, and alumni are studying and solving the most critical challenges facing education: student assessment, the achievement gap, urban education, and teacher shortages, to name just a few. Our work is shaping how people teach, learn, and lead in schools and colleges as well as in after-school programs, high-tech companies, and international organizations. The HGSE community is pushing the frontiers of education, and the effects of our entrepreneurship are improving the world.

title: Michael Bloomberg Harvard Commencement Speech 2014 | Harvard University Commencement 2014
desc: Michael R. Bloomberg MBA '66, an entrepreneur and civic leader who built an information technology company into a global news and financial information service and served three terms as mayor of New York City, was the principal speaker at the Afternoon Program of Harvard's 363rd Commencement. "Mike Bloomberg's career represents a rare blend of public leadership, private-sector entrepreneurship, and powerful philanthropic engagement," said Harvard President Drew Faust.

[LAUGHTER]        419    00:16:06.220 --> 00:16:10.240    But basically, either    way, you can't go wrong.        420    00:16:10.240 --> 00:16:13.260    I look at all of you and    see America's President of the United States.        423    00:16:20.040 --> 00:16:23.140    Those are all positions    of such great influence.        424    00:16:23.140 --> 00:16:24.540    Understand that    one title: Preet Bharara's Speech at Harvard Law School Class Day 2014
desc: Preet Bharara, U.S. attorney for the Southern District of New York, was the keynote speaker on Class Day.
speech_raw: 1    00:00:02.590 --> 00:00:07.530    Dean Minow, distinguished    faculty, proud parents, family,        2    00:00:07.530 --> 00:00:10.710    friends, and members of the    Harvard Law School Class        3    00:00:10.710 --> 00:00:14.980    of 2014, congratulations to you.        4    00:00:14.980 --> 00:00:18.600    You have so much to be    proud of, and so very much        5    00:00:18.600 --> 00:00:20.370    to be grateful for.        6    00:00:20.370 --> 00:00:24.450    I want to congratulate by name    the four most awesome members        7    00:00:24.450 --> 00:00:27.280    of the class of    2014, because they        8    00:00:27.280 --> 00:00:32.400    used to work for me-- Edeli    Rivera, Kyle Wirshba, Heather        9    00:00:32.400 --> 00:00:34.394    Alpino, and Claire Guehenno.        10    00:00:34.394 --> 00:00:35.060    Congratulations.        11    00:00:40.640 --> 00:00:43.180    This is a proud day    for everyone who        12    00:00:43.180 --> 00:00:46.900    is here-- but for the    parents, I think, especially.        13    00:00:46.900 --> 00:00:49.040    And not just for the    graduates' parents,        14    00:00:49.040 --> 00:00:50.840    it turns out that my    own parents are here.        15    00:00:50.840 --> 00:00:54.580    My mom and dad are    seated in the third row.        16    00:00:54.580 announcement    that Harvard Law School put out        19    00:01:05.820 --> 00:01:07.360    about the program.        20    00:01:07.360 --> 00:01:11.000    And he tells me that he and Mom    were going to come up for it.        21    00:01:11.000 --> 00:01:15.000    And I say to him, "Dad,    look, I'm really touched.        22    00:01:15.000 --> 00:01:17.610    But you don't have to drive    all the way up from New Jersey.        23    00:01:17.610 --> 00:01:20.260    You just had knee    surgery--it's a long haul.        24    00:01:20.260 --> 00:01:21.960    It's fine, Dad.        25 00:01:30.910 --> 00:01:37.100    How could I not come and    miss a once in a lifetime        28    00:01:37.100 --> 00:01:41.950    chance-- once in    a lifetime chance        29    00:01:41.950 -->     39    00:02:21.880 --> 00:02:24.640    curious about how the decision    making process worked.        40    00:02:24.640 --> 00:02:28.547    Like, how did that    meeting go exactly?        41 title: Graduate Address: Jon Murad | Harvard Commencement 2013
desc: Jon Murad delivers the Graduate Oration at Harvard's 362nd Commencement at Tercentenary Theatre on May 30, 2013.        Each spring, the Harvard Commencement Office holds a competition to select an undergraduate speaker, a graduate student speaker, and a Latin speaker. At Morning Exercises on May 30, the chosen three gave their addresses before an audience of tens of thousands gathered in Tercentenary Theatre.        For more information on this year's Commencement, visit http://news.harvard.edu/gazette/.

title: Undergraduate Address: Felix de Rosen | Harvard Commencement 2013
desc: Felix de Rosen delivers the Undergraduate Oration at Harvard's 362nd Commencement at Tercentenary Theatre on May 30, 2013.        Each spring, the Harvard Commencement Office holds a competition to select an undergraduate speaker, a graduate student speaker, and a Latin speaker. At Morning Exercises on May 30, the chosen three gave their addresses before an audience of tens of thousands gathered in Tercentenary Theatre.        For more information on this year's Commencement, visit http://news.harvard.edu/gazette/.

title: J.D. Speaker Josie Helen Duffy speaks at HLS 2013 Commencement
desc: At the 2013 Commencement Ceremonies on Thursday, May 30, 2013, J.D. speaker Josie Helen Duffy urged her classmates to "embrace the grey area," and not only become lawyers, but "fighters, peacemakers, preachers and engineers." Duffy reminded her classmates to help people on a daily basis, especially people that they might not expect to help.        Read more: http://www.law.harvard.edu/news/spotlight/student-pursuits/commencement_2013.html

You know what kind of    life you should live. You don't need an        329    00:16:38.490 --> 00:16:41.660    ethics course to tell you what not to do.        330    00:16:41.660 --> 00:16:44.620    Trust in your instincts and you will    build a great life        331    00:16:44.620 --> 00:16:46.120    you will build a good life        332    00:16:46.120 --> 00:16:48.220    and you will change the world.        333    00:16:48.220 --> 00:16:51.420    You know, I said at my age that I don't    have written much specific wisdom to        334    00:16:51.420 --> 00:16:52.520    impart        335    00:16:52.520 --> 00:16:55.190    I have one final piece of advice        336    00:16:55.190 --> 00:16:56.780    for the graduates        337    00:16:56.780 --> 00:17:00.760    and it is a piece of advice that is    gained from        338    00:17:00.760 --> 00:17:03.490    experience not books.        339    00:17:03.490 --> 00:17:05.459    Trust me about this.        340    00:17:05.459 --> 00:17:10.140    You will never understand how much your    parents love you until you have children        341    00:17:10.140 --> 00:17:12.559    of your own.        342    00:17:12.559 --> 00:17:15.630    Once you have children of your own,        343    00:17:15.630 --> 00:17:20.000    once you have children of your own, all    that strange behavior- the stalking, the        344    00:17:20.000 --> 00:17:23.900    worrying- it all makes sense.        345    00:17:23.900 --> 00:17:25.510    But do me a favor        346    00:17:25.510 --> 00:17:27.260    don't wait so long.        347    00:17:27.260 --> 00:17:31.140    My mother lives eight thousand miles    away and I think about this every day.        348    00:17:31.140 --> 00:17:33.100    Don't wait so long.        349    00:17:33.100 --> 00:17:37.830    Get up today of all days and hug your    parents and tell them you love them.        350    00:17:37.830 --> 00:17:40.690    Thank you ladies and gentlemen, and to the graduates of Harvard, godspeed.

title: Student Orations || Harvard University Commencement 2012
desc: Michael Velchik, Latin oration    Anthony Hernandez, undergraduate oration    Jonathan Service, graduate oration        Once a series of thesis defenses, often presented in Latin, Greek, or Hebrew, Harvard's Commencement orations have evolved into succinct five-minute speeches. Each spring, the Harvard Commencement Office hosts a competition to select an undergraduate student, a graduate student, and an undergraduate speaking in Latin for the occasion.        Here, the Class of 2012 orators share their stories â€” and a glimpse at the words of wisdom they plan to offer.

title: Seamus Heaney || Harvard University Commencement 2012
desc: Seamus Heaney was awarded the Nobel Prize in literature in 1995. He was teaching at Harvard that year, as he had been, one way or another, since 1979.        May 24 â€” bluff and kind and 73 â€” Heaney was back at Harvard, on hand from Dublin to read a poem at Morning Exercises. As Harvard celebrates its 375th anniversary, he will reprise his 1986 "Villanelle for an Anniversary," composed for the University's 350th.

title: George Hayward's 2011 Harvard Commencement Speech at Currier House
desc: No matter how rich or poor we become, no matter how big or small we may be, each of us will experience pain, and setbacks, and defeats. This suffering connects us in a tapestry of empathy, an unspoken understanding among us all that life can knock us down. It is with this in mind that I have decided to share the Harvard Commencement Address I delivered 5 years ago today at Currier House. I had hoped my father would see me graduate because he had helped me so much along the way, but unfortunately he did not make it. It has taken me a great deal of analysis to conclude that ultimately he was there all along. If I could give this speech again, I think I would make it funnier, but that was not my feeling at the time. So I stood there, looking out at a sea of faces in black robes, and with a heavy heart I began. But as I spoke I grew more comfortable, and then something caught my eye. Something I will never forget. Way in the back, behind the final row, there stood a man. He had no cane, no walker, no hospital gown. And then he winked at me. And when I saw my father wink, I smiled back because I finally knew that he was happy. I looked aside for a second, and when I turned back he had stepped away, but my heart now was light. I knew he was still here, just temporarily out of sight.    -George Hayward, May 26, 2016

title: Harvard Commencement 2010: David H. Souter speaks

title: Jamie Dimon:  Address to HBS MBA Class of 2009, Class Day June 21, 2009
desc: James "Jamie" Dimon (MBA 1982), chairman and CEO of JPMorgan Chase & Co., who has been listed by the Financial Times as one of the leaders most likely to lead the world out of the financial crisis, offered wide-ranging words of wisdom and advice to members of the Harvard Business School MBA Class of 2009 at Class Day exercises on the HBS campus. Also attending were family members, friends, and other guests of the almost 900 graduating students.        Focusing first on career management, Dimon reminded the class of the importance of lifelong learning and building a reputation-a personal brand-for hard work, integrity, and trust, among other qualities. In a sense, he said, a book is put together about each of us as we go through life, and "you can choose the way you want the book to be written."        As leaders face the challenges and opportunities of life, he continued, emotional intelligence is as important as brain power. "IQ alone won't get you through tough times." A dose of toughness was also part of the prescription Dimon proposed. People in positions of responsibility are bound to take some heat along life's way, he noted, quoting Theodore Roosevelt's observation that players are the ones who are criticized, not the spectators in the stands. He also underscored the importance of maintaining work-life balance. When it comes to family, he said, there is no such thing as quality time without an equal amount of quantity.        Moving on to the leadership of organizations both big and small, Dimon noted first the sense of responsibility he felt as a CEO: "If I make a mistake, I can hurt a lot of people," he said, from the bank's employees to its stockholders and stakeholders. He then discussed the wide array of attributes that every leader needs:        - Self-discipline, a work ethic, and a dedication to continuous improvement    - Fortitude and a penchant for action    - The ability to set high standards of performance and integrity. "Compare yourself to the best," he advised, "and treat other people the way you treat your parents. Do the right thing, not the expedient thing."    - Analytical skills that take a hard, honest look at all the facts, including "things we're not doing well."    - A willingness to share information with others and to use it as the basis for making the right decision. For that to happen, everyone a leader works with should feel free to engage in open, uninhibited conversations and discussions. "Have many truth tellers around you, not just one."    - A sense of the importance of loyalty, meritocracy, and teamwork in the context of the success of the entire organization. If someone is not doing the job, loyalty to organization trumps loyalty to the individual, Dimon explained.    - A feel for a firm's morale - something that can be severely damaged by organizational bureaucracy and politics    - Respect for everyone at every level, from the CEO on down    - A skill set that can "get compensation right" based on hard work and contributions to the company, including helping other employees. Long-term deals for CEOs and other top executives don't pass muster with Dimon ("I shouldn't have to bribe you to join us."), nor do compensation programs that automatically penalize failure. Leaders should be able to adjust for the fact that a person tried but ended up being wrong, he said.    - A sense of humility, based on the acknowledgement that no one rises to a leadership position without the help of others, beginning with one's parents.        The final portion of Dimon's remarks dealt with the leader's obligations to companies and society. JPMorgan is a "caring company," he said. "We give away $100 million a year, we pay the salaries of employees who have been called to military service, we send money and aid when disasters strike around the world," but at the same time, Dimon pointed out, "all these good deeds are predicated on the fact that my colleagues and I keep JP Morgan healthy and vibrant. Success is not a given."        Dimon urged the HBS graduates-to-be to play a role in helping make effective public policies that contribute to spreading wealth, not destroying it. There is a great need to make the planet better, he said. On the other hand, current energy policy, he believes, skirts the one solution that will work, namely taxation, and half the children in US inner cities don't graduate from high school. Much needs to be done in these and other realms. "I hope that I'm leading my life in such a way so that when I'm gone, people will say that the world is a better place for my having been here," he concluded.

title: Bill Gates Harvard Commencement Address 2007
desc: Bill Gates addresses the Harvard Alumni Association in Tecentenary Theater at Harvard University's 2007 Commencement Afternoon Exercises
speech_raw: 1    00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:21.490    Our next speaker, first known as the entrepreneur of the personal computer revolution, was named by Time magazine as one of the hundred people who most influenced the 20th century.        2    00:00:21.490 --> 00:00:35.654    As well as one of the hundred most influential people of 2004, 2005, 2006 and again in 2007.        3    00:00:35.654 --> 00:00:40.549    Just think what you could have achieved...        4    00:00:40.549 --> 00:00:43.523    [Laughter.]        5    00:00:43.523 --> 00:00:46.894    ...if you had stayed here another 2 years.        6    00:00:46.894 --> 00:00:57.400    [Laughter and then applause.]        7    00:00:57.400 --> 00:01:02.162    He enrolled at Harvard in the fall of 1973.        8    00:01:02.162 --> 00:01:07.280    Keenly interested in computer science but without a definite study plan.        9    00:01:07.280 --> 00:01:10.319    [Some laughing.]        10    00:01:10.518 --> 00:01:18.759    In between intense poker games at Radcliffe, he met his future business partner, Steve Balmer.        11    00:01:18.759 --> 00:01:25.271    And he developed a version of the programming language Basic for the first microcomputer.        12    00:01:25.271 --> 00:01:33.869    And co-authored and published a paper on algorithms, with computer scientist Christos Papadimitriou.        13    00:01:33.869 --> 00:01:38.906    Our speaker is a person of many talents.        14    00:01:38.906 --> 00:01:48.500    A close friend in college amusingly recalls seeing him dose of during a prestigious Putnam math exam.        15    00:01:48.502 --> 00:01:53.768    Despite this napping he scored remarkably well.        16    00:01:53.768 --> 00:02:02.360    In his junior year he took a leave of absence from Harvard to devote his energies to Microsoft.        17    00:02:02.361 --> 00:02:08.440    A company he had begun in 1975 with his friend Paul Allen.        18    00:02:08.894 --> 00:02:15.469    Since 2000 he has begun to concentrate on a number of philanthropic endeavors.        19    00:02:15.469 --> 00:02:26.449    Making extraordinary donations to various charitable organisations and scientific research programs around the world, through the Bill and Melinda Gates foundation.        20    00:02:26.449 --> 00:02:32.120    After a 33 year leave of absence from his alma matter.        21    00:02:32.125 --> 00:02:37.030    I am pleased to present to you Doctor William Gates.        22    00:02:37.228 --> 00:03:04.929    [Standing Ovation.]        23    00:03:04.929 --> 00:03:07.118    Thank you.        24    00:03:07.118 --> 00:03:20.507    President Bach, former president Rudenstine, incoming president Faust, members of the Harvard corporation and the board of overseers.        25    00:03:20.507 --> 00:03:25.657    Members of the faculty, parents and especially the graduates.        26    00:03:25.657 --> 00:03:31.687    I've been waiting more than 30 years to say this.        27    00:03:31.687 --> 00:03:37.980    Dad I always told you I'd come back and get my degree.        28    00:03:37.980 --> 00:03:49.116    [Applause and some laughter.]        29    00:03:49.116 --> 00:03:53.159    I wanna thank Harvard for this honour.        30    00:03:53.159 --> 00:04:00.826    I'll be changing my job next year and it will be nice to finally have a college degree on my resume.        31    00:04:00.826 --> 00:04:02.560    [Laughter.]        32    00:04:02.565 --> 00:04:09.020    I applaud the graduates for taking a much more direct route to your degrees.        33    00:04:09.020 --> 00:04:16.910    From our- my part I'm just happy that the Crimson called me Harvard's most successful drop out.        34    00:04:16.910 --> 00:04:22.600    I guess that makes me valedictorian of my own special class.        35    00:04:22.603 --> 00:04:26.246    I did the best of everyone who failed.        36    00:04:26.246 --> 00:04:29.227    [Laughter.]        37    00:04:29.227 --> 00:04:36.700    But I also want to be recognised as the guy who got Steve Balmer to drop out of business school.        38    00:04:36.702 --> 00:04:43.080    [Laughter and then also applause.]        39    00:04:43.080 --> 00:04:45.440    I'm a bad influence.        40    00:04:45.443 --> 00:04:50.799    That's why I was invited to speak at your graduation.        41    00:04:50.799 --> 00:04:57.830    If I'd spoken at your orientation fewer of you might be here today.        42    00:04:57.830 --> 00:05:02.889    [Laughter then also applause.]        43    00:05:02.889 --> 00:05:06.507    Harvard was a phenomenal experience for me.        44    00:05:06.507 --> 00:05:09.330    Academic life was fascinating.        45    00:05:09.334 --> 00:05:14.607    I used to sit in on lots of classes that I hadn't even signed up for.        46    00:05:14.607 --> 00:05:17.137    And dorm life was terrific.        47    00:05:17.137 --> 00:05:20.610    I lived up at Radcliffe, in Courier House.        48    00:05:20.611 --> 00:05:22.890    [Cheering.]        49    00:05:22.894 --> 00:05:31.875    There were always a lot of people in my dorm room late at night discussing things, because everyone knew that I didn't worry about getting up in the morning.        50    00:05:31.875 --> 00:05:33.828    [Laughter.]        51    00:05:33.828 --> 00:05:37.450    That's how I came to be the leader of the antisocial group.        52    00:05:37.453 --> 00:05:42.680    We clunged each other as a way of validating our rejection of all those social people.        53    00:05:43.217 --> 00:05:46.190    Radcliffe was a great place to live.        54    00:05:46.804 --> 00:05:51.787    There were more women up there and most of the guys were math-science types.        55    00:05:51.787 --> 00:05:56.597    The combination offered me the best odds, if you know what I mean.        56    00:05:56.597 --> 00:05:59.159    [Laughing.]        57    00:05:59.159 --> 00:06:06.418    That's where I learned the sad lesson that improving your odds doesn't guarantee you success.        58    00:06:06.418 --> 00:06:08.920    [Laughing.]        59    00:06:08.922 --> 00:06:15.700    One of my biggest memories of Harvard came in January 1975.        60    00:06:15.704 --> 00:06:24.699    When I made a call from Courier House to a company in Albuquerque, New Mexico, that had begun making the worlds first personal computer.        61    00:06:24.699 --> 00:06:27.580    I offered to sell them software.        62    00:06:27.584 --> 00:06:33.516    I worried they would realise I was just a student in a dorm and hang up on me.        63    00:06:33.516 --> 00:06:38.638    Instead they said, we're not quite ready, come see us in a month.        64    00:06:38.638 --> 00:06:43.140    Which was a good thing because we hadn't written the software yet.        65    00:06:43.144 --> 00:06:44.495    [Laughing.]        66    00:06:44.495 --> 00:06:56.780    From that moment I worked day and night on the extra credit project that marked the end of my college education and the beginning of a remarkable journey with Microsoft.        67    00:06:56.780 --> 00:07:05.050    What I remember above all about Harvard, was being in the midst of so much energy and intelligence.        68    00:07:05.054 --> 00:07:12.555    It could be exhilarating, intimidating, sometimes even discouraging but always challenging.        69    00:07:12.555 --> 00:07:24.430    It was an amazing privilege and though I left early, I was transformed by my years at Harvard, the friendships I made and the ideas I worked on.        70    00:07:24.433 --> 00:07:31.949    But taking a serious look back, I do have one big regret.        71    00:07:31.949 --> 00:07:48.099    I left Harvard with no real awareness of the awful inequities in the world, the appalling disparities of health and wealth, and opportunity, that condemn millions of people to lives of despair.        72    00:07:48.099 --> 00:07:53.820    I learned a lot here at Harvard about new ideas and economics and politics.        73    00:07:53.822 --> 00:07:58.686    I got great exposure to the advances being made in the sciences.        74    00:07:58.686 --> 00:08:09.160    But humanities greatest advances are not in its discoveries, but in how those discoveries are applied to reduce inequity.        75    00:08:09.163 --> 00:08:19.230    [Applause.]        76    00:08:19.231 --> 00:08:31.800    Whether through democracy, strong public education, quality health care or broad economic opportunity; reducing inequity is the highest human achievement.        77    00:08:31.804 --> 00:08:41.740    I left campus knowing little about the millions of young people cheated out of educational opportunities here in this country.        78    00:08:41.741 --> 00:08:50.230    And I knew nothing about the millions of people living in unspeakable poverty and disease in developing countries.        79    00:08:50.232 --> 00:08:53.595    It took me decades to find out.        80    00:08:53.595 --> 00:08:59.026    You graduates came to Harvard at a different time.        81    00:08:59.026 --> 00:09:04.330    You know more about the worlds inequities than the classes that came before.        82    00:09:04.331 --> 00:09:18.710    In your years here I've hope you've had a chance to think about how in this age of accelerating technology we can finally take on these inequities and we can solve them.        83    00:09:18.714 --> 00:09:28.689    Imagine just for the sake of discussion that you have a few hours a week and a few dollars a month to donate to a cause.        84    00:09:28.689 --> 00:09:36.749    And you wanted to spend that time and money where it would have the greatest impact in saving and improving lives.        85    00:09:36.749 --> 00:09:38.400    Where would you spend it?        86    00:09:38.405 --> 00:09:42.330    For Melinda and I the challenge is the same.        87    00:09:42.331 --> 00:09:47.680    How can we do the most good for the greatest number with the resources we have?        88    00:09:47.684 --> 00:10:03.078    During our discussions on this question, Melinda and I read an article about the millions of children who are dying every year in poor countries from diseases that we have long ago made harmless in this country.        89    00:10:03.078 --> 00:10:09.329    Measles, malaria, pneumonia, hepatitis-b, yellow fever.        90    00:10:09.329 --> 00:10:17.068    One disease that I had never heard of, rotavirus, was killing half a million children each year.        91    00:10:17.068 --> 00:10:19.680    None of them in the United States.        92    00:10:19.684 --> 00:10:21.710    We were shocked.        93    00:10:21.714 --> 00:10:33.368    We had assumed that if millions of children were dying and they could be saved, the world would make it a priority to discover and deliver the medicines to save them.        94    00:10:33.368 --> 00:10:34.950    But it did not.        95    00:10:34.954 --> 00:10:41.858    For under a dollar there were interventions that could save lives that just weren't being delivered.        96    00:10:41.858 --> 00:10:53.106    If you believe that every life has equal value, it's revolting to learn that some lives are seen as worth saving and others are not.        97    00:10:53.106 --> 00:11:02.307    We said to ourselves this can't be true, but if it is true it deserves to be the priority of our giving.        98    00:11:02.307 --> 00:11:09.420    So we begin ou- began our work in the same way anyone here would begin it.        99    00:11:09.423 --> 00:11:14.550    We asked, how could the world let these children die?        100    00:11:14.554 --> 00:11:17.197    The answer is simple and harsh        101    00:11:17.197 --> 00:11:24.969    The market did not reward saving the lives of these children and governments did not subsidise it.        102    00:11:24.969 --> 00:11:33.750    So the children die because their mothers and fathers hadno power in the market and no voice in the system.        103    00:11:33.750 --> 00:11:36.610    But you and I have both        104    00:11:36.613 --> 00:11:45.890    We can make market for- forces work better for the poor if we can develop a more creative capitalism.        105    00:11:45.891 --> 00:12:00.130    If we can stretch the reach of market forces so that more people can make a profit or at least earn a living, serving people who are suffering from the great inequities.        106    00:12:00.132 --> 00:12:11.829    We can also press governments around the world to spend tax payer money in ways that better reflect the values of the people who pay the taxes.        107    00:12:11.829 --> 00:12:27.079    If we can find approaches that meet the needs of the poor in ways that generate profits for business and votes for politicians, we will have found a sustainable way to reduce inequity in the world.        108    00:12:27.079 --> 00:12:30.500    Now this task is open ended.        109    00:12:30.501 --> 00:12:38.250    It can never be finished, but a conscious effort to answer this challenge can change the world.        110    00:12:38.252 --> 00:12:41.816    I'm optimistic that we can do this.        111    00:12:41.816 --> 00:12:46.369    But I talk to skeptics who claim there is no hope.        112    00:12:46.369 --> 00:12:57.166    They say inequity has been with us since the beginning and will be with us until the end, because people just don't care.        113    00:12:57.166 --> 00:13:00.870    I completely disagree.        114    00:13:00.871 --> 00:13:06.586    I believe we have more caring than we know what to do with.        115    00:13:06.586 --> 00:13:15.786    All of us here in this yard, at one time or another, have seen human tragedies that broke our heart.        116    00:13:15.786 --> 00:13:17.236    And yet we did nothing.        117    00:13:17.236 --> 00:13:22.210    Not because we don't care, but because we didn't know what to do.        118    00:13:22.211 --> 00:13:26.240    If we had known how to help we would have acted.        119    00:13:26.242 --> 00:13:31.360    The barrier to change is not too little caring.        120    00:13:31.363 --> 00:13:33.478    It is too much complexity.        121    00:13:33.478 --> 00:13:41.897    To turn caring into action, we need to see a problem, see a solution and see the impact.        122    00:13:41.897 --> 00:13:46.020    But complexity blocks all three steps.        123    00:13:46.022 --> 00:13:57.190    Even with the advent of the internet and 24 hour news, it is still a complex enterprise to get people to truly see the problems.        124    00:13:57.192 --> 00:14:02.207    When an airplane crashes, officials immediately call a press conference.        125    00:14:02.207 --> 00:14:08.480    They promise to investigate, determine the cause and prevent similar crashes in the futures.        126    00:14:08.481 --> 00:14:23.140    But if the officials were brutally honest, they would say, "Of all the people in the world who died today from preventable causes, 1 half of 1 percent were on this plane.".        127    00:14:23.144 --> 00:14:31.660    We're determined to do everything possible to solve the problem that took the lives of 1 half of 1 percent.        128    00:14:31.660 --> 00:14:39.220    The problem is not just the plane crash but the millions of preventable deaths.        129    00:14:39.225 --> 00:14:49.520    We don't read much about these deaths, the media covers what's new and millions of people dying is nothing new.        130    00:14:49.522 --> 00:14:53.608    So it stays in the background where it's easy to ignore.        131    00:14:53.608 --> 00:15:01.229    But even when we do see it or read about it, it's difficult to keep our eye- eyes on the problem.        132    00:15:01.229 --> 00:15:10.740    It's difficult to look at suffering if the situation is so complex that we don't know how to help and so we look away.        133    00:15:10.741 --> 00:15:19.180    If we can really see a problem, which is the first step, we come to the second step.        134    00:15:19.180 --> 00:15:23.800    Cutting through the complexity to find a solution.        135    00:15:23.801 --> 00:15:30.570    Finding solutions is essential if we want to make the most of our caring.        136    00:15:30.573 --> 00:15:40.710    If we have clear and proven answers any time an organisation or an individual asks, "How can I help?", then we can get action.        137    00:15:40.714 --> 00:15:45.710    And we can make sure that none of the caring in the world is wasted.        138    00:15:45.710 --> 00:15:55.340    The complexity makes it hard to mark a path of action for everyone who cares and makes it hard for that caring to matter.        139    00:15:55.342 --> 00:16:03.299    Cutting through complexity to find solutions runs through 4 predictable stages:        140    00:16:03.299 --> 00:16:07.609    Determine a goal. Find the highest impact approach.        141    00:16:07.609 --> 00:16:17.040    Deliver the technology ideal for that approach and in the mean time use the best application of technology you already have.        142    00:16:17.045 --> 00:16:23.200    Whether it's something sophisticated like a new drug or something simple like a bed net.        143    00:16:23.205 --> 00:16:32.480    The aids epidemic offers an example, the broad goal of course is to end the disease.        144    00:16:32.484 --> 00:16:43.700    The highest leverage approach is prevention, the ideal technology would be a vaccine that gives life long immunity with a single dose.        145    00:16:43.701 --> 00:16:50.655    So governments, drug companies and foundations are funding vaccine research.        146    00:16:50.655 --> 00:16:54.100    But their work is likely to take more than a decade.        147    00:16:54.116 --> 00:17:03.600    So in the mean time we have to work with what we have in hand and the best prevention approach we have now is getting people to avoid risky behavior.        148    00:17:03.607 --> 00:17:08.400    Pursuing that goal starts the 4 step cycle again.        149    00:17:08.444 --> 00:17:10.400    This is the pattern.        150    00:17:10.432 --> 00:17:15.971    The crucial thing is to never stop thinking and working.        151    00:17:15.971 --> 00:17:22.973    And never do what we did with malaria and tuberculosis in the 20th century.        152    00:17:22.973 --> 00:17:27.298    Which is to surrender to complexity and quit.        153    00:17:27.298 --> 00:17:43.200    The final step after seeing the problem and finding an approach, is to measure the impact of the  work and to share that, success or failure, so that others can learn from the efforts.        154    00:17:43.215 --> 00:17:53.000    You have to have the statistics, of course, you have to be able to  show for example that a program is vaccinating million more- millions more children.        155    00:17:53.024 --> 00:17:59.780    You have to be able to show for example a decline in the number of children dying from the diseases.        156    00:17:59.780 --> 00:18:08.800    This is essential not just to improve the program but also to help draw more investment from business and government        157    00:18:08.824 --> 00:18:16.167    But if you want to inspire people to participate, you have to show more than numbers.        158    00:18:16.167 --> 00:18:21.593    You have to convey the human impact of the work.        159    00:18:21.593 --> 00:18:27.600    So people can feel what saving a life means to the families affected.        160    00:18:27.637 --> 00:18:39.600    I remember going to the World Economic Forum some years back and sitting on a global health panel that was discussing ways to save millions of lives.        161    00:18:39.625 --> 00:18:42.300    Millions.        162    00:18:42.328 --> 00:18:50.000    Think of the thrill if you could save just one persons life, then multiply that by millions.        163    00:18:50.038 --> 00:18:55.196    Yet this was the most boring panel I had ever been on-        164    00:18:55.196 --> 00:18:56.100    [Laughter.]        165    00:18:56.149 --> 00:18:57.100    -ever.        166    00:18:57.143 --> 00:19:02.300    So boring that even I couldn't stand it.        167    00:19:02.306 --> 00:19:16.800    What made that experience especially striking was that I had just come from an event where we were introducing version 13 of some piece of software, and we had people computer and the internet.        179    00:20:23.073 --> 00:20:26.552    Give us a chance we've never had before.        180    00:20:26.552 --> 00:20:32.000    To end extreme poverty and end death
